reviewText: This movie is cheerful, positive, comic and with outstanding graphics. Loved the story and characters. Not to be missed.

The Following review was published on Rancho Santa Fe Review, Carmel Valley News, We Chinese in America, and:

featured on NPR (National Public Radio):
[...]

Animation World Network (my press junket photo, Dragon drawing):
[...]

Perry's Previews:
[...]

----------------
How could a wimpy kid who is so different form everyone else defy others' expectation and become a true hero and leader?

In the new DreamWorks animation action-adventure thriller "How to Train Your Dragon," Hiccup, an eccentric adolescent with a weak build but a strong sense of humor, lives on the Island of Berk, a bustling place full of imposing, muscular Vikings, led by "Stoick the Vast," the Viking Chief and the father of Hiccup, who could not hide his disappointment for his only son.

In Berk, fighting swarms of nightmarish dragons is a way of life for centuries.  Gobber, the comical blacksmith and dragon fighting coach, is one of Hiccup's few true friends.  Gobber lost his arm and leg from earlier dragon fighting.  He has a unique "no-nonsense" style of training, making his apprentices "throw themselves at the dragons."  He figures that the ones who survive will surly survive on the battlefield.

Another genuine friend of Hiccup's turns out to be one of a different kind: a "Night Fury" dragon, the most intelligent and mysterious kind that nobody else had ever seen before.  One dark night, Hiccup captured an unseen creature with his own flying net.  The next day, he saw the Night Fury dragon: pitch black, fierce, but also injured and helpless.  Seeing the fear in its eyes, Hiccup set it free, a crime against the Viking's code of conduct!  Hiccup repaired the injured dragon's tail which he had shot off, and gave him his favorite food: fish.  In return, the dragon (whom Hiccup named "Toothless") took him on many thrilling flights and revealed to him the deepest secrets of dragons.

The secrets of dragons gave Hiccup a surprising edge in his dragon training, which shocked the formerly most promising Viking teen, Astrid, a new character absent from the original book.  Astrid, a hardworking and super-competitive girl, gradually warmed up to Hiccup as he shared his hidden world.

The problem is that Viking's sworn enemies are dragons, and with that risk, Hiccup cannot keep Toothless a secret forever...

In the end, Hiccup became an unexpected hero, using his hidden power, ultimately redeeming himself and changing the lives of every Viking villagers, forever.

My favorite part of the film is how Hiccup tamed Toothless.  The scene when Hiccup reached out his hand for Toothless to touch for the first time, is the most magical scene in the film.  My favorite character is obviously Hiccup, who seemed wimpy and different at first, but is the one with true power inside.  Hiccup and I also share a passion for dragon and drawing.  I was born in 2000, the year of the Dragon, and consider myself a "Dragonologist," one of my favorite books that I own is "How to raise and keep a dragon."  I have drawn so many different kinds of dragons and made tin-foiled animal sculptures of dragon.

More importantly, Hiccup and I share a gentleness, innocence, and kindness towards other living creatures which enabled us to tame wild animals: dragons for him and a deer for me.  I still remember vividly how a beautiful deer approached me and licked my hand and head at the San Diego Wild Animal Park when I was three years old and just moved to San Diego from San Francisco.  I noticed that the deer did not lick any other kids even when they petted her.  It is easier to tame an animal when it has no fear for you.

"How to Train Your Dragons" is an epic tale packed with adventure, action, humor, stunning 3D visuals and beautiful music.  I give it 4.5 starfish, it is as good as Up!  It is a film that I think every child and parent will love to experience.  The movie is about friendship, connection, redemption, and the hidden power of "being different."

This is the first time that I am invited to a film's press junket, held at the luxurious 5-star and 5-diamond rated Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills on March 20, 2010.  What an experience!  I gave it 5 starfish rating myself: I got to pick TWO favorite toys in the gift basket the moment my mom and I arrived, and another gift when we were checking out!  The fragrant air smelled like orchids and cinnamon, the food is amazing, and the service is even better.  Stacy, the nice waitress and I became instant friends.  I had a blast at the swimming pool with two boys from New York and London.

The coolest part of the press junket was interviewing directors Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders, voice talents Jay Baruchel (Hiccup), America Ferguson (Astrid), and Craig Ferguson (Gobber).

When I shared my 4.5 starfish rating, the directors and actors were all curious about the missing half starfish.  I asked them: How could Hiccup survive flying on the back of Toothless at 50,000 feet in the air, without suffocating or freezing to death?  Directors Sanders and DeBlois laughed and joked that they would make sure to prepare oxygen tank and protective gear for Hiccup next time.

America Ferguson laughed so hard when I said, "I guess it's poetic license," and became my instant fan!  America thought Astrid added a lot to the story because "she was the best and always challenged Hiccup to be the person he should be."  Craig Ferguson, who played Gobber, challenged me to take flying lessons.  He said the best part of his role in the film was not having to dress up for work!

Unlike "Hideous Zippleback," the two-headed dragon in the film whose two heads fight all the time, directors Sanders and DeBlois have a warm friendship since their "Mulan" collaboration and share similar tastes in the kind of movies they like to make.  What happens when you disagree?  I asked.  "Usually we make coupons for each other, so that if one of us wins this argument, the other can use the coupon to win the next one," said DeBlois.  Asked about the stunning designs of various dragons in the film, Sanders said, "We worked with a terrific artist who designed over a thousand different dragons, some from the book, others from his own imagination.  Some of them are as good as yours!"  He was referring to my Chinese Imperial dragon I drew last year at Disney D23 expo.

Jay Baruchel and I shared thoughts about being different as I asked him how he drew his own life experiences to play Hiccup.  "I remember all the other kids outside playing soccer or hockey when I was growing up, but all I wanted to do was reading comic books, watching cartoons, or write stories.  I was different just like Hiccup, and I always think of myself as the one with true power inside," said Jay, "You need to be proud of how different you are, because difference is what makes the world interesting.  The people who have everything come easy, who don't have to fight for anything, who are everyone's favorite all the time, they don't have anything interesting to say."  I couldn't agree more!

"How to Train Your Dragon" is not only a thrilling action adventure, but also a tale with deep emotion and strong morale: Friends are more powerful than foes.  Being different empowers you to see what others cannot see.

Liane Hansen, National Public Radio (NPR) host of Weekend Edition Sunday interviewed me about "How to Train Your Dragon," on Sunday, March 28, 2010. NPR is the leading national radio program with over 30 million listeners worldwide. You can listen to my interview here:

[...]

How to Train Your Dragon is the latest from the stable of Dreamworks, but apart from the animation style, you'd never know it.

How to Train Your Dragon is the story of Hiccup, a Viking who feels out of place since he's not a fan of killing the dragons the Viking's world so revolves around in. But, when Hiccup captures the rare Night Fury Dragon and inadvertently injures it, the two become fast friends and attempt to bridge the gap of understanding between the Dragons & the Vikings. It may not sound like much, but things are deeper than they may seem here, and they are 3 reasons you need to go out and watch this movie right now.

1: Casting: Having seen Jay Baruchel as a geeky character in the film Fanboys, this film only solidifies for me the fact that Baruchel makes cliched characters feel real & brings traits out they wouldn't have otherwise, and this fact is very evident here. The same is true for the rest of the cast. In Shrek 2, Larry King was wasted in a long-running and painful transvestite joke. Here, Craig Ferguson is perfect in the role not only because he's Scottish, but he brings the appropriate mix of eccentric leadership needed for the right-hand man of Gerard Butler's character, who is also well cast. The same goes for the rest of the cast with the possible exception of Jonah Hill, who always feels out of place in almost every movie he's in.

2: Visual Effects & 3D: Now this may because the Viking environment hasn't been portrayed much on screen before, but the film is stunningly beautiful, and that's only reinforced by the 3D which is used better than Avatar in some cases, especially in the case of the flying sequences.

3: The Emotion/Uniqueness of the Film in Animation Today: The story gives way to many emotional moments in the film, all of which are played perfectly. And, not to give too much away, but at the end of the film something happens the to main character that was not only shocking to me, since I'd never seen something of its magnitude done in animation period, but to me it was also one of the most tear-jerking moments, especially in relation to what it does to the relationships & similarities between Hiccup & his dragon in the movie.

Overall, how do you train your dragon? With charm, love, understanding, amazing visuals & stunning 3-D flying sequences. This film ranks up there with Pixar's best, and if I had any criticism towards the movie, it would be the fact that it's made by Dreamworks, and with their quality lately, you don't have high expectation entering this film. Nevertheless, How to Train Your Dragon gets a fire-breathing 5 out of 5.

... there lived a boy who couldn't quite live up to the bar his father set for him in his life. Despite his efforts, he usually failed to the chagrin of the town and the man (his father) who was its leader. Hiccup (a quite apt and funny name for this lad) one night decides to prove himself by launching a trap for the nefarious "Night Fury" dragon, and surprise, he snags one. Finding it wounded in the forest, the boy learns not only how to care for and train his dragon, but also, how to find his own unique footing in his life. Such is the tale of the heart warming and wonderfully vivid family family, "How to Train Your Dragon."

Created by Dreamworks, which always seems to be in the shadows of the superstar Pixar, has finally come into its own with this cinematic experience. One of the first things you might notice is the spectacular flying sequences between Hiccup and Toothless. The magic of the animation is spotless, and what even makes it more breathtaking is the fact that there is little to no dialogue in these scenes. That adds to the splendor of seeing Hiccup fly, both literally and symbolically, over his village and life.

Dreamworks concentrated on the usual Pixar strengths, of story, of character, of heart. This movie has all three, and all three in spades. The ending of the movie, which shant be revealed here, is one worthy of a few Kleenex. I, a somewhat cynical and hardened viewer to sentimental scenes, was totally taken off kilter by the enchanting surprise of emotion embedded in the context of the film. Dreamworks nailed it.

Parents, be wary of very young kids seeing this film. I would have no problems having my second grader on up seeing this film, but anyone younger may have trouble with some scary dragon scenes, especially towards the end, warranting the PG rating.

However, what lingers with me after seeing this movie is the strong relationship threaded throughout, esepcially between our hapless hero Hiccup and his man-killing dragon Toothless. For "How to Train Your Dragon" is in itself a wonderful metaphor, for never judging people too harshly before one gets to know them a little bit, and the benefits reaped when one does. A bit adventure, a bit fun, a bit emotional, all makes for a wonderful time at the movies.

The first Shrek and Kung Fu Panda were both very close to Pixar level in terms of storytelling, but How to Train Your Dragon is the best by far from Dreamworks. The animation is very high in detail, especially in IMAX 3-D, and the characters are not only likeable, but memorable. The main dragon, Toothless, is one of the greatest animated characters in a long time, and like Wall-E, he doesn't even talk. All of the other species of dragons also have unique looks and personalities. The flying sequences here really show the power of 3-D as a tool to put the viewer in the movie, not just a gimmick. I would say it's second only to Avatar when viewed through those funny looking glasses.

This film is more serious in tone than laugh out loud funny, much like the latest from Pixar (UP, Wall-E, etc.), but it does have quite a few laughs that come naturally, not forced. I'm so glad they stayed away from pop culture references. Both kids and parents will love How to Train Your Dragon equally and probably for much different reasons. The only thing that I didn't care for were the first 10 minutes or so. Not that they are bad in any way, but it felt a little rushed. Once the film settles and Hiccup (the boy viking) meets the dragon, everything begins to click. The only other negative is that every kid is going to want a pet dragon for their birthday. Good luck with that!

While most folks reviewed the movie itself, I was particularly interested in the Specials. If you get the 2015 version of the Blu-ray, yo do not get all of the specials that were released with this version (from back in 2010). Most folks may not realize that. I have no idea why they removed most of the special features in newer releases, but this release has everything that I wanted and then some.

Pop up trivia - not really in depth, but basically with this turned on while watching movie, gives texual snippets throughout the movie.
Animators corner is fairly interesting - Give a PIP (Picture-in-picture) while the movie is playing. Might show the actor recording the voice at that time, the animator working out some details, etc.
The Technical Artistry of Dragons - Sort of the making-of the technical aspects of the movie, such as how the different types of fire was designed, etc.
Viking-sized Cast - The interviews and recordings of the actors.
Bunch of other stuff you might come to expect. Some DVD games, deleted scenes, interview with the person who wrote the original books, etc.

The movie itself is a great movie. No need to elaborate on that. All in all, it is a great buy.

It's literally one of the best movies I've ever seen. It is beautifully animated, and it has a beautiful message. Every time I throw it on, I end up happy-weeping. I happy-weep just thinking about my favorite moments.

Funny, drop-dead funny, in fact.  Beautifully animated and voiced by an all-star cast.  At once an excellent coming-of-age story as well as a story of listening to the facts of an issue before making up one's mind.  15-year-old Hiccup, son of Viking chieftan Stoick the Vast, is a gangly misfit who doesn't quite fit in to his "place" in Viking society, and with good reason.  A well-told tale of learning to look beyond common knowledge into what is actually true and accepting others for who they are, not who we wish them to be.  Excellent for all ages.

So after being inspired by Game of Thrones and buying my very own dragon from a guy on Craigslist, I figured the next thing to do was learn how to train it before it got out of control and barbecued half the people in the neighborhood.
This DVD looked the very thing to help me do that. Unfortunately, on viewing said DVD I discovered that it wasn't a 'Dragon Whisperer' type of thing as I'd first thought, but an animated movie by DreamWorks.
Never mind, turns out it was a pretty fantasmagorical movie with some breathtaking animation that took my breath away and has yet to return it, which means I've now had to learn to breathe underwater until I save up enough money to buy some second-hand oxygen.
Luckily there were a few tips in the movie about how to actually 'train your dragon' but when I tried those things with my dragon it couldn't do any of them. The dragon in the movie was called toothless but mine was more like useless, so that's what I named him.
When 'Useless' still couldn't fly after a few weeks I became suspicious and inspected him more closely. It was only then that I discovered that I'd been ripped off and my 'dragon' was actually the Loch Ness Monster with a pair of flimsy fairy wings stuck on its back. When the authorities heard about it they made me ship 'Useless' all the way back to Scotland at my own expense. That's the last time I buy anything from craigslist.
Oh, well, at least the DVD was good, and you can still enjoy it, with or without your own dragon.

We have been trying to encourage our son to read more, but were having difficulty finding things that held his interest.  One day I decided to try something new.  For Christmas we gave him presents in pairs.  The book and the movie together.  He now takes the time to read on his own, as well as with us.  Realizing that he gaining more information and a different point of view with characters he already knows helps him explore in areas he loves.  This particular piece also helps him understand that being unlike everyone else is not a bad thing.

Do NOT watch if you've read the book. This is not a 5 star film even if I wouldn't have read the book. So many things wrong with it.

False Advertising
The words: "Based on the book by Cressida Cowell" is a lie. Taking scene, character names and title is not even "Loosely based". It is NOT "How to train a dragon". But not that Hiccup is a brave 10 year old boy who grows into a hero who is truly tasked with finding and training a dragon like all the other warriors in his home village. This movie should be called "How to kill 2 dragons", "How to tame a dragon" or "How to get along with your father who hates all dragons".

I am sorry if I have set the bar higher when it comes to my kind of entertainment. I am just tired of being tricked into watching a film with a guy flying passed rocks like Luke through the Deathstar or Harry Potter on Buckbeak with the standard dramatic, enormous battle scene and the unnecessary, overused boy gets girl scenes.

We really, really liked this movie!  My 9-year-old son and I watched it together.  Contrary to a couple of negative reviews, I didn't find it boring at all -- it was funny (without a ton of potty humor or innuendo), touching, exciting, and had a feel-good ending. My son and I also observed, as sort of a moral to the story, that those who are angry and vicious are not changed by more anger and viciousness returned to them, but by kindness! The movie wasn't super violent -- however, there is the potential for younger kids to be frightened by the scary dragons.  I would guess that as young as an 8-year-old should be able to enjoy it without having bad dreams.

The storyline met expectations in a not-necessarily-good way (can't say there were any real surprises).

Fortunately, the cast met expectations in a way that was good. It was an interesting move, casting Scottish guys as the adult Vikings. Gerard Butler and Craig Ferguson pair off quite well.

The characters also blossomed nicely. I particularly like how Astrid (America Ferrera) starts out as a bully then takes on another dimension. The main dragon, Toothless won me over as well. (Not too shabby for a non-speaking part.)

The animation certainly met my high expectations. Kudos for that. The flight sequences were especially impressive.

Overall, this was very nicely done, and I enjoyed the second viewing more than the first.

Our absolute favorite animated movie

Okay, I recently watched the new movie Training your Dragon 2. It was fantastic. I did a review saying that it was, and I also went so far as to say "it might even be better than the first." So, I got to thinking...I hadn't seen the first one since it first came out. I decided to watch it again. Wow. This is such a GREAT animation. There just isn't enough space to write the review that HTTYD#1 truly deserves! The characters, the dragons, the color, and the indescribable humor and happiness you feel as you watch Hiccup and Toothless interact and become hero's, best friends, and the beginning of acceptance into a society that was set in an unyielding, ancient ideology. Our own society could learn a great deal from this victorious animation. My hat goes off to the Author, Cressida Cowell (she allowed a great deal of leeway, and a huge change of her original story) she allowed them to make one of the best animation movies I've ever seen! Bravo, ma'am!

A really well-made and entertaining movie that's suitable for the whole family. How to Train Your Dragon was suggested to me by a friend and I was reluctant to watch it at first, but I'm glad I did - it's easily one of my favorite 3D animations. The visuals are all beautiful, the story is engrossing with a good mixture of adventure, coming-of-age, and romance, the characters are likeable and entertaining, the acting is spot-on, and the humor is frequent and well-played. I particularly enjoyed the many cute traits of the dragons that are a blend of some of the most adorable behaviors of common household pets.

Here's yet another great film that I missed the boat on initially. I typically stay away from kid's movies (save classic Disney) because they tend to be overly simplistic bores that would only entertain the youngest of children. HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON is one of best of the lot, however, because of its excellent animation and a compelling story with themes that will resonate with viewers of all ages. The movie takes place in an indeterminate time period when Vikings and dragons coexisted, although not peacefully as the beginning makes perfectly clear. They're mortal enemies, in fact, and Vikings train from a very young age to be able to kill the beasts who raid their village and steal their livestock. Everyone, that is, except Hiccup. Hiccup is what you could call an outcast or a reject. He wants to join his peers in training, but nobody ever seems to want to give him a chance. Fortunately, he gets one, though not in the way you'd expect. As the title indicates, there is some dragon training that goes down, but not without a serious paradigm shift. At its core, this movie is about a young boy who doesn't quite fit in, yet finds a way to make himself valuable to the people around him. There is also a subtext about learning to empathize and/or come to terms with things that we don't understand, and therefore fear. Both of these messages are very pertinent to people, young and old, and are dealt with in a mature, yet accessible way. For the kids, you have the spectacle of expertly animated flying sequences and a killer battle with the big-bad dragon. For adults (and more discerning children), you have the meatier stuff about acceptance and overcoming your fears. It's really one of the best animated films I've ever seen, on multiple levels. While DreamWorks might have made their name with Shrek, I think that this will have a bit more staying power in years to come. In fact, this is so good that it pains me to even gripe about a single thing, so I'll make it brief. The setup of the movie is a bit roughly handled, and the characters (initially) aren't really given their due. But the movie improves drastically as it progresses, so much so that you almost forget the slightly weak first act. Overall, this is a movie I see myself watching again and again, and I'll definitely be checking out the sequel. Do yourself a favor and go watch this right now. You'll be glad you did.

Gorgeous movie, of course, but I wanted to address the things that come with this, as they're not listed in the description. This dvd includes the original How To Train Your Dragon movie along with an episodes of "Dragons: Defenders of Berk" (the tv show based of the film), the short film "Legend of the Boneknapper Dragon", various deleted scenes from the film itself, and filmmaker commentary. I didn't know this edition had any extras when I purchased it, and I was delighted to find them along with the movie. This is a great collection of little Dragon-esque things for a good price.

A classic story of an insatiable dragon dictator and increasing taxes and regulatory control.  The rank-and-file dragons must have been initially pleased with the cradle to grave protection and support system devised by the great elite master dragon complete with warm and comfortable housing and plentiful food to be had.  When we join the unfolding saga in the opening scenes of the movie, we see that the regular working dragons are having to collect more and more of other peoples' food to (as we later find out) satisfy the great dictator dragon's demands for satisfaction.  At first, the Scandinavian villagers whom are losing much of their precious livestock to the increasingly frequent raids by the hard- pressed worker dragons, don't understand why they are being robbed over and over again and their very survival is now at stake and face starvation in the winter despite their best efforts at protecting themselves and their livestock from the dragon raids.  The abuse of power by the master dragon finally ends when the worker dragons and the villagers unite and destroy the tyrannical master dragon and live happily ever after.  So happy, in fact, that there is a sequel!  If you listen carefully to all the excellent dialogue written for all the characters, including the entertaining and terrific readings by notable Hollywood actors, the subject of liberty never comes up in conversation per se but they really do seem to all like it a lot in the end.  I guess this movie did not do well at Sundance or Cannes-- or maybe they don't do cartoons.  I guess I don't care or I would google the subject and clarify it now.

I also like how it took dedication and effort for the lead character to build a relationship with the dragons and become a dragon rider.  A couple of things which bothered me though were the stereotypical father/son relationship, and how differently the adults were characterized vs. the children - note how all the adults speak with a Scottish(?) accent, but none of the children do.  Almost like the children came from someplace else.  It was a rather unnecessary us vs. them element to the characters.

DreamWorks How to Train Your Dragon may suffer from an odd title, but it certainly grabs your attention. Thankfully, the brilliant animation, characters, and a pleasant variation on the traditional a boy and his dog plot keep that attention.

HTTYD quickly brings you in with its main character, Hiccup, voiced by Jay Baruchel. He is a nerd/outcast archetype, something Baruchel seems to have found himself typecast as, but there is something of a sincerity to his voice and identifiability to his problem of not living up his fathers expectations. These are things that weve all seem before, but they are still welcome here because there is a genuineness to the performances in this film. Hiccup has a great sarcastic sense of humor, and the other teen characters help give the film authenticity, in spite of all the flying fire-breathing reptiles. Theres Astrid (America Ferrera), Snoutlout (Jonah Hill), Fishlegs (Christopher Mintz-Plasse), twins Ruffnut (Kristin Wiig) and Tuffnut (T.J. Miller). The bit of the Appatow gang thats present here lend their improv skills to some the humorous conversations, and it works to the films benefit. Gerard Butler and Craig Ferguson also work great as the village chief and Hiccups dad Stoick and blacksmith Gobber respectively.

Where this film really shines, other than the characters, are the visuals. The seas and skies are painted wonderfully. This is especially evident in the scenes where the characters are riding the dragons as mounts. The filmmakers knew that this would be the highpoint in the film, and special care was taken to beautifully and artfully depict the sensation of flight, as well as the creatures agility and speed.

The plot can follow some predictable turns, as the archetype here is a boy and his dog but the twist that keeps this film going the fact this is a pretty cool dog. A dragon. And yes, the little boy in me screams awesome! at riding a dragon. It really is something that simple that drives this film, how awesome it would be to have a dragon as a pet. What propels this film to being great is the seriousness of the conflicts and the identifiable characters. A great one from DreamWorks, whose reputation is slowly approaching Pixar-like proportions. I'm always a little skeptical of recent films that receive near universal praise.  It's almost as if standards are getting lower and what is mediocre is now great and what is actually great is nearly non-existent.  This is a poignant example.

How to Train Your Dragon has an abundance of good reviews so, statistically, you might find yourself in that bucket and be reasonably pleased.  All hype aside, HTTYD is a pretty uninspiring story. You can guess the entire plot within the first few minutes.  Boy is an outcast, boy finds dragon, boy trains dragon, boy saves the day and becomes a hero.  The end.

Now maybe this movie won't break ground in originality, but the execution is pretty poor too.  Nothing exceptional happens.  For anyone who has already seen this movie, I would ask "What were some memorable lines?" and "Who were some memorable characters?".  The responses, I suspect, would be depressingly lackluster.

I judge a movie by how much you retain after seeing it--whether there was some profound, emotional scene, a clever joke, or an enchanting musical score.  If you don't have any of these things after watching, you know it's a low-scoring movie.
Kids love the movie...how could they not! Great movie that perfectly illustrates that fear of the unknown is fear from our minds, not from reality.

Toothless is worth mentioning in his own sentence. As a dragon, he is a formidable opponent but with Hiccup he's cute, well-written, and fun. The bond they share is truly heart-warming. If you haven't seen this movie yet, go see it!

Jay, a fellow Montrealer, knocked me over with his down-to-earth, slightly goofy character.
The music is solid and energetic - I also listen to that every time I get a chance, although the CD is more (a bit too much) intense compared to the movie - I prefer the actual soundtrack.
The animation is first rate, so are the flight physics and charisma of the creatures in the story.  You can tell that the animators spent a lot of time studying many types of bird flight, and your typical home pet personalities.
Story line is good for adults and kids.

I thought the audience was misdirected, themes were adolescent. Purpose of the movie and introduction of each character and dragon was an obvious effort to sell toys. That sort of business bores me. The relationship between the boy and the dragon was flat, the presence of the other slew of adolescent characters (excepting the father and the viking with the missing arm and leg) and their eventual dragons were too brief and flat that the whole thing just fizzled and bored me (and my kids).

Great themes of forming unlikely friendships, fighting for what you think is right, overcoming disabilities, etc.  A couple things to note, this is not at all the story from the book.  They just borrowed the title and some of the characters and made an entirely different story.  Also, there were some references to the polytheistic Nordic gods.  Just an appropriate nod to the culture of the people they're portraying, but something to be aware of for my Judeo-Christian friends since little ones might question why the characters are referring to gods in the plural or god-characters they might not have ever heard of (Thor, Odin, etc).

This is truly a tour de force of the animation and movie world.  How To Train Your Dragon is simply stupendous, a must-see, and worth every penny you might spend on it.

A young boy named Hiccup doesn't quite fit in with his Viking brethren considering his size, his affinity for clumsiness, and its destructive outcomes.  With a father called Stoic who leads the island home and community, Hiccup is determined to continually prove himself.  This desire manifests itself in the wish to kill a dragon, the pests that steal the food of the Vikings and burn down their village more often than not.  When Hiccup manages to shoot down a Night Fury, the dragon that nobody ever sees and never misses its target, his entire life changes along with his understanding of the creatures that are so very dangerous.

The story is about friendship, trust, beauty, sacrifice, and understanding.  It's so well done that you instantly fall in love with Hiccup's demeanor and the Night Fury, Toothless.  Not only is the story stupendous, but the animation is something to applaud as well.  Smooth, seamless, and perfectly modern.  Along for the ride are the great voice actors, the script, and the score which sends pleasurable chills down my spine every time I hear it.  The entire package couldn't be much better than what it is.
If I had to pick a top 5 for movies, How to Train Your Dragon would be in it. I just love this movie.

The filmmakers have taken the classic "Villagers Terrorized by Monster(s)" premise, and given it texture, warmth and humor.  The characters are easy to identify with - not stereotypes, but folks with flaws and strengths as you'd find in any small town. The movie plot may have nothing in common with the books, but in this case, I'm actually going to say that's OK-- they're both brilliant in different ways. This movie is one of the only ones I've ever seen where the hero is not just compassionate and brave, but *observant*, and *experiments with things*-- which don't always work!-- and *build stuff*. He's a problem-solving engineer, and that's just a wonderful example to have in such a fun adventure. Add to that the excellent supporting character of Astrid, who is very much *not* your stereotypical animated-movie girl (tough, competent, a fighter, observant enough to actually notice when things are weird, and open-minded enough to change her mind so not going for the dumb fighter-girl stereotype either) and this is one of the few kids' movies I wouldn't hesitate to give my younger relatives. On top of that, it's a fun story as suitable for adults as kids, with an *adorable* and very personable dragon and tremendously beautiful graphics. Well done-- I'm looking forward to the sequel.
This was a fun family movie!  I would recommend it for any family. I hope you enjoy it too. Now to watch the sequel.

Both my toddler sons enjoy this movie and watch it over and over again.  The story line is good and the dragons are fun for the boys.  While my sons' enjoy it, I think girls would too.  Fun Family Entertainment.

Action packed adventure with a good plot. About a young boy who is has different values but out performs his peers in a very unexpected way. We're going to watch it again!
Matt
My 20 year old introduced me to this movie. It is so cute.  Well done. Holds  your attention at any age.
I am not embarrassed to admit that I love this movie, even though I am a 24 year old male. This was the perfect lazy day rental for my girlfriend and I.
My daughter LOVES this movie.  Great story of using kindness over strength.  You totally fall in love wih hiccup and toothless.

I love this show because it is very entertaining for kids as well as adults. It is a very well done Feel Good Movie.
I seen it a couple of times and will watch it again in the future. I highly recommend it to anyone wanting to watch something light and fun and well done.

This movie holds my kids' attention and the humor is enough to keep me interested. It moves at a good clip and so far I've seen it at least 27 times and don't want to pluck my eyeballs out of my head... yet.
My kids like this movie enough that we now have a few dragon toys and a dragon cape.
Awesome movie. ( I saw this at the theater) but I do not recommend amazon live stream! The playback often stops to continue loading in the middle of the movie, or just doesn't play at all

I love this movie so much! It's an instant classic and it's great for kids about 7 and up. Especially great if you're a lover of dragons! I have a Toothless stuffed animal above my bed :)

Worth buying!

the story line was not what I expected and kept my interest in the different characters in the movie, but the main character showed determination and also ingenuity solving the various problems he faced.
Great movie, entertaining with a nice message.  I loved it as much as my kids did - a new favorite!

I rented this for my 3 year old grand son.  We watched it 3 times during the 48 hour rental period.  The next weekend, I have forgotten to lock my Kindle and he rented it for himself.  I have since purchased it as he absolutely loves it.
I love this movie! One of my favorite animated films of all time! It's 2nd only to the original Ice Age.

An amazing movie for the entire family, entertaining, educating, and no-nonsense.
The story is captivating, with a few twists in plot.

Highly recommended!
So different from the movie. Interesting thing is that the difference make them both better. I love the take the movie has on the story.
Super cute.  The 5 year old sleep over loved it and I loved it too.  I think my 8 year old girl will enjoy it as well.
Good movie. My son and I really enjoyed it.  There is a little violence with fighting dragons but it has a good message
My son, who is 39, had this posted on his wish list; so we bought it and watched it with him.  It was wonderful and very entertaining!
This movie is excellent - the story, the artwork, and beautiful cinematography. It know when to be funny and when to be emotional. A truly great animated film!
I got this mainly for my grandson, but I found it very entertaining. So now, my grandsons parents have gotten the series of books pertaining to the training dragons.
I'm not sure who enjoys this movie more, the kids or the parents. For once in our parental life, a movie has not gotten old

This is a lovely story with fun characters (especially the dragon!), humor, and the right amount of sentimentality.  Just as expected from Dreamworks.  We saw it in 3D at the theater first - that was fun too.
Great movie for families! We rented the movie on our smart tv and it worked great. The humor was tasteful and fun.
Great Movie! Great young movie to watch with the family. It will take you on a dragon adventure with action, excitement, and love.
My favorite movie of all time.  Need I say more? Funny, positive, engaging, fun.  The little ones may be a bit scared in the beginning.  Love it!
What a great movie - my two year old and I really love it - will buy more on demand.

I think our family review of this movie is summed up best by my child saying thank you in his prayers that dad picked this movie for him to watch.  Warms my heart.

The movie is about Vikings who have to protect themselves from various types of dragons that attack them so, as you can imagine, there is some violence.  I would refer you to the parents' guide on IMDB.com for details on the violence.  It certainly wasn't enough for me to keep my kids from watching it.
Great characters and loads of action make this a terrific animated movie for everyone. It's hard not to fall in love with Toothless!
Good Cartoon for kids, Funny for Adults too, As long as you can get past the main characters quirky voice, good for one watch at least

My son and I started watching the "Defenders of Berk" series and wanted see how it all started. A GREAT movie for young and old. My 4 year old was able to follow the story, the Dragons are not too scary and it all works out in the end...but not too quickly as is my concern with many children's movies...not enough focus on the resolution of the conflict. It's a movie about kids for kids with some cool dragons and realistic adults...and I loved it too! The graphics are spectacular...highly recommend it as a family movie.

My granddaughters have watched this movie time after time and never get tired of it. I have seen it several times now, and still enjoy it. The message, that we can conquer our fears by learning about that which we fear, is strong and timely.
Before I saw this amazing movie, my dragon was out of control. It was eating sheep, and starting fires everywhere. Thank you Hiccup!
Ask anyone if they've seen "How to Train Your Dragon", and they will tell you it is a must-see.  The movie has an excellent soundtrack and story line, combined with good, clean humor.
My child loved it.  I thought it was a great inspirational story that really defines the word "Different" as "Special"
the bluray edition is awesome love this movie and the features are cool too came sooner than i anticipated thank you

Our younger son wanted this movie, but the whole family enjoyed watching it together which is a rare occurrence in our house. At just $3 for the 48-hour rental, it was very affordable family entertainment.  Our son watched it again and again during the rental period and has now added it to his list of all-time favorite movies and wants us to buy the movie for him for Christmas.

Solidly entertaining for all audiences.

This is a show that, like cars, can be watched and enjoyed by the who family.  Plenty of clean mature humor and lots of fun for kids to watch.

Highly suggest.

Perfect for your bluray player, it really shines when played that way. The details are rich and sharp, with zero blur. This is a movie to play if wanting to show off what your new high def TV/bluray combo can really do.
The movie itself, of course, rocks. A great story line and really good voice acting and great animation put forth a near perfect movie, suitable for all ages. Buy it, you won't be disappointed!

Great for the whole family. Cute, funny, great entertainment. Grand-kids keep watching, can not get enough.
Teaches value lesson for children.

This is a really fun and unique movie! It can be a bit scary for really young kids at times. There are no princesses and only a little romance...I don't know why so many kid's movies have to be about falling in love with a prince. Ugh.
The artwork was fun. Artistic profiles on the characters were great. The soundtrack was excellent. Storyline was well done. Throw Gerard Butler in and there is nothing bad I can say about this movie.

My family and I love this movie.  We wondered if it was a little violent for our young children, but even though there is LOTS of peril, no one ever seems to die!  At least they don't ever show it.  Great family film.

My daughter wanted to watch this 10 times she loved it!

I recommend this for any family with or without kids!

I might be a big kid, but this movie is still fun to watch again and again.  We can't wait until summer of 2014 for the release of the next movie.  Also, having the double pack ensures we can watch the movie regardless of DVD players available.
How to Train Your Dragon was super cute and completely original. I loved it! I will definitely add it to my collection.
My grandkids love it and we watched while we travelled this summer, so nice to have to keep them entertained in the car.

Great fun for any age who enjoys animated movies. Great voice cast and outstanding story and animation make this one of the best animated
Movies I've seen in a along time. I rank it with Ice Age, Brave, or any other that comes out in recent years.
My kids, 6 and 5 year olds, love the movie. I watch it with them too. Love all the characters
Take it for what's its worth and don't delve into hidden motives with this movie. Great clean fun that had me captivated from the theater
Best movie I've watched in a long time. Great characters, story line and lesson. Well done!! You should see it
Great movie. Great lesson. Great story. Really a cute story and fun for kids. (mine have loved it since two years old.)
I was babysitting some kids after I bought this and they were dying over how great this movie was. It's a great film for parents and kids.
My wife and I love watching this movie again and again, and with the Blu-ray combo it is even more fun all in one!

This movie was wonderful. The animation is incredible. I almost forgot I was watching an animation it was so realistic. A great story and lots of characters to root for and identify with.
Highly recommend this one to everyone.

Hiccup, an unusual Viking, wants to be like the rest of his kin.  He invents a device to bring a dragon down and learns dragons aren't quote what they've been raised to believe.  In a sense, the same applies to the dragon.

This is tale boundaries and ultimately learning the truth for yourself.

The graphics are good.  The characters are cute and appropriately developed.  Humor is interspersed throughout the story.

Overall, a fun and heartwarming tale!
We have a 10yr old and 8 yr old and we are very picky right now as to what they are allowed to watch. This was a perfectly 'clean' movie and the overall story was excellent!
This movie was very imaginative and fun. It kept me wanting more. A great film, excited about the second one coming soon.
My kids love this movie and they ask to watch it all the time. It has a cute story and is really funny!
good message; no weird sexual undertones like in some kids shows; no strange humor; funny without being over the top; love Toothless characterization

Many would say animated films are for kids but I disagree! I'm 18 and I love this movie as it is one of my top 3 favorite (excluding classics) animated films (megamind and wreck it ralph are the other 2).
Overall it has a very well put together storyline with lots of emotion, action and comedy. It causes you to sympathize with each of the characters getting you "into the movie" very well. And toothless is amazing/cute/fabulous/awesome/muchmore!
If you are looking for a great movie to add to you collection, a family movie, a movie for the kids, or just a good movie in general I recommend "how to train your dragon" any day!

Didn't know what to expect but fell in love with it.  Haven't watched it again yet ... but will.  Love the story ... and the dragon.  And the relationship between the boy and everyone else.  If I had grandkids we'd be watching this all the time!

It's a great film with subtle humor and intense filled action! However, it is a family film, so if you don't want a lesson about how "everyone should be treated right" or "even the most dangerous creatures have a soft-spot," then I wouldn't click this film. I do enjoy it immensely.

Watched this when it first came out and loved it. Just watched it again with my girlfriend a couple nights ago and she LOVED it. Which led to her making out with me because I chose a great movie. So yea, thanks DreamWorks :)
Good stuff; good for adults and children. Didnt love the main character's voice; but the story's a good one; clever too.
Enjoyed this film. Parents and their children can learn something from it when it comes to communicating with each other.

This movie far exceeded my expectations. I don't know why, but I didn't think it was going to be anything special.
Goodness, I was so wrong! This movie is magical. Plain & simple. It is one of those movies that I would turn on even if the kids were gone. ;)
It makes me want a dragon of my own! I highly recommend this movie to anyone with kids (and even those without)!
Kudos to story tellers Chris and Dean. Fine photographic effects from Roger Deakins adding that 'special touch.' Very enjoyable. Kid's love it.
I gave as a gift but as far as I know the boy is still wathcing it over and over he loves it best gift he got along with some other DVDS bought
My kids loved the movie and so did my husband and I.  The message to be who you are regardless of others around you was great for my girls to see.

This is from the perspective of a childless adult who loves a good story.  The pacing was well done for the most part. The animation was high quality, emotive and cartoony enough to avoid the uncanny valley.  I could go off on some inconsistencies in the narrative and places where disbelief had to be suspended just a few notches higher, but it is a fairy tale. Fairy tales do not need rigor, they need setting, characters, and just a hint of a moral.  As such, this was a good entertainment.

This is my favorite movie!
Awesome story, well made, and the music is awesome. I watch it at least once a week.
What a great movie with so many life lessons mixed in amongst colorful characters and really creative dragons. Highly recommend for the whole family!
Original, well thought out movie.  It was really enjoyable and a movie I could watch over and over again. A must see.

While this movie was marketed as a kid's movie, it's wonderful for all ages!  Even at the age of 20, I still love watching many of the wonderful Dreamworks movie, this one included.

Whether it's the wonderful animation or the compelling story you enjoy, you'll find yourself rooting for the adorable Hiccup and his dragon Toothless.  I loved this movie so much, I actually found myself shedding a few tears at Hiccup's and his father (Stoick "The Vast") and the way the skinny boy was constantly misunderstood by his disappointed, and much larger, father.

If you like good animation and a wonderful, heartwarming story, then you'll love How to Train a Dragon - I know I did!

I had already seen "How to Train Your Dragon" so I knew I would enjoy the movie before I requested it. I also had already used Amazon's instant movie renting system. Things went just as I expected and the movie was good. Every so often it did freeze however while we were watching it which was a little frustrating.

The relationship between Hiccup (the main character)and Toothless (the Dragon) Has to be one of the sweetest, truest friendships I have seen in a while. Everything about this movie is so heartfelt and the animation is amazing. I LOVE this movie.
My kids watched this 2 days straight. They loved the adventure! Great story about being different and staying true to your heart.
This is my favorite animated movie. Ever. I can't say enough good things about this movie. Everyone can enjoy this.
My wife and I have been meaning to see this for a while now and we were not disappointed.  Kids are not required to enjoy it haha!

I'm tired of people complaining about how the movie wasn't as good as the book, they never are.... as a parent i enjoyed sitting down with my family and watching this film, it was good had funny moments, a little drama and the important partvwas the kids liked it. Totally recommend
Item was delivered promptly. It looks great, as described. Another son birthday present. :) we have watch this movie so many times, it's time to own it. :)
I highly recommend this movie. The storyline is intriguing, the characters loveable, and it will not disappoint you. Great action and you will feel like you are in the movie!
Such a fun story and great way to learn not to judge a book by its cover.  Also teaches about understanding others motivations will teach you why they are who they are.
I bought this movie for my 6 year old boy who of course likes all things reptile and dinosaur-- dragons included. It's a movie even I like although a bit on the P.C. side.

We first saw this when it came on tv.  Our 3y/o really latched onto it and for over a month we had to watch it every day, sometimes 2-3 times a day.  I finally decided to purchase the DVD for him for Christmas.  The dvd/blu-ray discs have held up tp a lot of abuse from him (he likes to help put the disc in the player). is movie library has expanded a little since I purchased his so owe don't watch it as much, but still enjoy seeing it.

The movie itself has humor that has kept our 3y/o entertained as well as us.
I love this movie I watch it every all the time and the kids watch it all the time thank you its very action packed
Great movie, good for kids and adults alike. Blu-ray is required for me, it looks awesome! Too bad it didn't come with a digital copy at this price, though.
I love cartoon/animated movies.  This is up there with the best of them all. Solid good time for whole family or a date.
This was viewed by a group of teenagers 18-15.  They all loved the movie.  Now they all want to own a dragon.
this is my son's favorite movie and it doesn't hurt that it is entertaining and funny for the whole family!
Filled with comedy, colorful animation, and adventure, you'll love this dragon movie. Made for all genders and audiences, this movie will keep you laughing.
This movie is one that keeps you questing what is next and keeps you on the edge of your seat! I loved it!
I recommend this for kids who love dragons. It will be worth it. Family time with kids is worth watching this movie.
This is a great animated video. Has very good storylines. All kinds of action and plenty of comedy. Good for all ages.
Well done story line and great animation. My grandkids were mesmerized. Recommend for kids and the young at heart. one.

I love this movie.  I didn't expect to, but the interaction between the main character and the dragon is so heart-warming.  I even bought a copy for my mom since she likes animated movies too.

This movie is great because it works through a lot of character development and relationship growth.  The main character learns to overcome his fears and that, by being himself, he can be a success - even if he does things a little differently than everyone else.  And his father, who initially is embarrassed by him, comes to see and value his son for who he really is.  Some pretty deep character development for an animated movie - which is awesome (too many animated films have a flat story and no character development).

Your kid will learn some great lessons, but they won't even realize that they are (because the movie is so much fun to watch).
It's funny too.  Something that will appeal to both kids and parents.
This is a great mix of family friendly, sci-fi, animation, and fun.  Some of the dragon fight scenes were a little scary for our 3 year olds, but the movie is great.
It is fun and adventurous. It teaches real values and has such a great story line. Plus the dragon is so cute!
this movie was Awesome. I could watch how to train your dragon everyday cause it was so awesome. It was a nice movie

When I first saw this a couple of years ago, I fell in love with it immediately.  I had to have it so I purchased it right away.  A couple of years later, and I'm still happily watching with a smile on my face.  The storyline is appealing and tugs at the heart, but not too much so that you don't feel forcibly manipulated.  The humor is appropriate and appreciated.  Aesthetics-wise, it's not as refined or pretty as other animated shows.  At times, it comes across as rather amateur compared to Pixar (the creature animation looks cheap), but that does not take way from my love of this movie.

We've seen this movie a few times, and my son really likes it, and the books by Cressida Cowell.  The movie is more conventionally plotted than the books, so if you've read them, you should be aware you might be disappointed in the film.
Witty and funny. A movie for all to watch together..How we all need to come together and live happily ever after

This is easily one of my favorite movies ever, not just animated, but of any genre. It's not perfect, and I know not everyone will like it as much as I will. Pretty typical "boy and his dog" kind of story, but the visuals are just completely breathtaking, this is the first movie with a flying scene where Ib really felt like I was flying, even without the 3-D! It's obvious that Dreamworks put a lot of heart, love, and talent into this movie, and it shows. The highest of praises from me!
Got this one for all my grand children, so when they come and visit this is what they pull out and load up the Blu-ray player with.
Pretty good. If you enjoyed Brave you will like this. Not great in my opinion, but watchable and fairly entertaining. Some very cool flying and fighting scenes.
I just love this movie! Great story and animation. I really hope there is a sequel made of this one.
I personally love this movie and it was an instant hit with my 3 year olds (as soon as they got over their fear of dragons). There is a good lesson and plenty of action.
It's no Pixar movie, but it is definitely enjoyable! Has all of the cheesy feel-good moments and conflicts that you expect.

I first saw this movie when I was substitute teaching for an AP art class the day after their exam. We watch the first 40 minutes or so together. Later that night I came home and rented it from Amazon because I was that interested in how it ended. It is a really fun movie with surprisingly good video quality given the streaming of the video.
I actually watched this movie last night after my kids fell asleep. My kids love it so much this was the replace the one they wore out.
I really loved this movie and my boys too! I wish that dragons were around like this movie!! Thumbs up ;)
This movie was really great for kids but funny enough the adults enjoyed it too!  The dragons reminded us of cats and we thought the movie was funny as well as sweet.

My son (8) loved this and my daughter (4) was also entertained. Better for kids a bit older than 4 though- there are some intense scenes of people being chased by dragons, though no blood and generally emotionally light in tone.
I had seen parts of it here n there but sat down one day and watched the whole film and fell in love with it.
We were searching for something to watch with our three year old that doesn't have violence. This has fighting, but to demonstrate that it is not the way to end conflict. So worthwhile, to my mind.

Movies that target the "coming of age" of a young boy help point us to something that is largely missing in our American culture - a distinctive action that ceremonializes and confirms a boys passage into the responsibilities of manhood.  And we miss the father's role in that.  I think this movie helps highlight both the role - positive or detrimental - that a father plays in his sons future manhood and the need a boy has to know that he has what it takes to be a man and not only a person.
My son begs to watch this movie daily and is now a fan of the series.  Good storylline and message, my older girls even enjoy it!
The animation is great.  I really like the plot and the morals that it teaches.  I have always been a fan of Disney and this movie did not disappoint.
Fantastic movie, excellent animation and a wonderful message all rolled into fabulous entertainment. Don't miss it. It should have gotten an academy award for best animation.

I never saw this in the theater, but I had heard about it from friends.  Finally taped it from a cable channel, and I fell in love with the story.  I've found that the really good movies are "redemption" themed, and this movie captures that and more.  Great movie for adults, great movie for young children. The imagery, together with the incredible music, is over the top!  I'll probably wear out the CD cuz another grand baby will need to enjoy it, too!

So cool to have the choice of DVD & BluRay.
Fun movie
In my 6 month rotation of must see movies!
Good watch with the kiddos, and even a movie I would watch without the excuse of children. A definite see.
The animation is very well done. The story itself is great and it is told well. The film is humorous and entertaining, appropriate for young and old.
I am a kid at hart 42 I love this movie every time I see on TV I just sat down and watch it so I just had to buy it
The kids thought it was somewhat entertaining but the "dragon" didn't look like a "traditional" dragon. More like a manta ray that flew imo. The storyline isn't so bad though.
This movie was such a nice surprise!  Nice change of pace from the Disbey run we'd been on for a while. Some real lessons for my little guy in this movie.
Great story with amazing graphics.  Love the personality of each dragon.  Great sense of humor with lots of ridiculousness thrown in
I think I know the father and son personally, all they need is the dragons! BluRay and DVD together is nice.

Watched this with my son on cable. Easily my favorite Dreamworks movie up to this point. Voice acting was great, story was great, we just loved everything about it. Finally got around to purchasing it on here.
I love this movie. It's so cute and heartfelt with action and neat animation. Even as an adult I could watch this movie at least once a week!
My family likes this movie.  The dragon's personality is really cute, all around good movie.  Can't wait to see the sequel.
My great niece loved this movie.  I found it on Amazon and pleased my grandsons, 5 & 2, by supplying a movie they had not seen.  It was great.

Really a great movie about so many topics - the love between a father and a son, a father grappling to let go of his expectations and embrace who is son truly is, how perceptions may be totally wrong, and how kindness and love can triumph against it all.  Wonderful film and wonderful message.
I love seeing this on the small screen, but this was the movie that made me realize how awesome it is to see animation on the big screen. Great movie!!!
My grandson just loves the actionand I love the fact that it has no cursing or any other sexual content
Watched with grandkids, and enjoyed the story line. Lots of fun. Good visual quality and DVD in good condition on arriving

This story is done by Disney's Pixar and what I love about this film is its story line.  Its well written and subject matter of the night fury dragon that befriends the Viking runt (Hickup) is a story that touches the minds and hearts.  The animation and detail put into this movie is also impressive.  If you are bordering the fence about buying this movie, and you have never seen it, I recommend spend the $ 2.00 dollars and rent it for two-or so days first and decide for yourself if its worth buying.  I've seen it on Encoure a few times in the past and it was one I thought made a nice edition to my video library.  Thanks, k
I'm semi-retired and I still love this movie.  Love the graphics and the story.  What can I say.....I'm hooked.  So, I bought it.
The movie was heartfelt, funny, and adorable! DreamWorks knocked it out of the park on this one. Toothless is the cutest

It is kind of a father - son conflict movie, where the father wants to kill dragons and the son befriends a dragon.  It is a very well done story as you would expect from the media moguls at Dreamworks.
I loved this in blu-ray. The detail is amazing. The color is sharp. The sound is fantastic, even better with a sound system. This is the only way to view this flick.

Pixar has definitely made an impact to always watch their newest production, however, after seeing "How to Train Your Dragon" I really feel DreamWorks has made a step in that direction. This movie has a lot of heart to it that you really don't expect and makes you wish that dragons were just chillin around in our every day life.
This movie is perfect for all ages. The quality starts off a little rough, but it gets better through out.
This is a great movie. Even my 9 year old son love to watch it. Great addition for your movie collection.
This is such a cute movie about a boy who tries hard to get his family to believe that they don't have to keep running from dragons, and that they can be pets.
Fun to watch for all ages.  The action keeps little one happy and the dialog and story line are good for the rest. Well done movie. A keeper for us.
The movie turned out to be better than I expected and the price I paid was a very good value.
Bought it 4 days ago and have watched it 4 times. Kids absolutely love it. Very fun movie with plenty of mild adult humor.
Great movie :) will watch it again and again. Good for all ages. Fun and funny. Heartwarming. Lessons learned. Awesome
Not really a movie for my 3 year old who spooks easy but super cute anyway. I loved it and would watch it again.
Me and my son have watched this movie several times and it never gets old. Great story with likeable characters
One of my favorites from Dreamworks! :) And such a great value with this package of blu ray + dvd!
We love this movie.  Our family has watched it at least a dozen times and just thoroughly enjoy it.  I would recommend it to anyone that likes a fun movie.
Great movie that my boys love to watch.  Very nice to have both blu-ray and regular DVD included in one set.

Uma serie animada bastante divertida, vikings e seus drages, resolvendo problemas e principalmente encontrando formas sadias de convivncia entre especies, certamente uma bela serie animada que foi iniciada por este filme, eu recomendo!
This was purchased for a teenager as a specific request for a Christmas present and the whole family watches it
Other than the Vikings having Scottish accents we loved this movie.  Two adults sat mesmerized by the graphics and the great story line.  But we assumed kids would enjoy it as well. LOL.

Great musical scoring, incredible animation, and a well written story line will keep you (and your kids) glued to the very end. The music is breathtaking and really helps boost the film to a new level. The animation is classic and well done. The story is well conceived and doesn't leave you hanging. A great one for a night in with the kids!

My daughter really loved this movie, and it turns out that I liked it a lot, too. It's very heartwarming without being mushy, and it has a solid moral core. The animation is pretty amazing, too. Definitely worth watching in HD.
My wife and kids can't stop laughing at this show. I enjoyed it quite a bit as well. Great animation, voice acting and humor. A must see.
I like animated movies that are good. this is one of them. Loved the movie. Highly recommend it. Wish it was cheaper like dvd rental from red box :)
The animation is great and the story line is one that amuses me time and again. This is an actual "family" movie we all can and do enjoy! Love it.
I love this movie just as much as the kids do!  Great family film.....can watch over and over again.  Highly recommend.

The work of computer animation in this movie is amazing and the the story very good too. My 3 year-old kids, my husband and I watched the movie several times already. There are so many details in this movie that every time we watch we find interesting things we hadn't paid attention before.
My grand son loved this show.  It has a good story line about how a boy changes the villages future.
I have watched it many times. I really like the scene where Hiccup and Toothless first bond over fish and drawing.
My two boys 6 and 8 both love this movie. We were away from home and it was great being able to stream it from Amazon.

Amazing movie! i really enjoyed this movie from beginning to end. awkward little kid just wishing he would fit in, sometimes being unique and awkward is a good thing :) im a nerd and looooove it :) and i have a sexy wife and two little nerd children>>>well hopefully they will be haha.
I love this movie! My niece and I watch it together all the time. Its very cute and very entertaining.
Such a great movie! One of dreamworks best! I would most definitely recommend this for children AND grown ups a ike!

I bought this movie through Amazon Instant video and downloaded it to my Kindle. I then watched it twice on the plane during my round trip travels. This movie is fun and light an perfect to kill some time. And it worked perfectly on instant video.

I rented the movie and was not able to stream it.
It would stop and load too many times.
Finally I stopped and streamed it from VUDU, which turned out to be a much better service and flawless.
This movie had a surprising plot to the story and that's what makes it interesting. The picture and sound is theater quality when viewed in 1080p. Recommended Blu-ray to add to any collection
My boys 6 and 8 and I enjoyed this movie a lot.  Has a fresh story line and the characters are fun.  I dig the soundtrack also.

There's nothing I don't like about this animation, from the characters to the drawing to the story. I have the original book, which has very little to do with the story here, and I think I like the movie better.

I think the only reason this didn't do better was because it was in competition with Disney/Pixar when it came out but it's an excellent movie. Truly gorgeous textures and details make this look good even now when Brave has come out and made the digital animation of hair a new technology.  The characters are all engaging, all relatable, the parent-child interactions way, way better than Brave, and the dragons are just very cool. It's probably too violent and chaotic for little kids (it opens with a night time battle scene), but for anyone older, it's fun and it's engaging for adults so no one gets bored. And while the lead is a boy, the best warrior in his age group is a girl. The geeky kid who knows all the Dungeons and Dragon stats is as useful and funny as the kids who have courage or mechanical skills and women work and fight alongside men as equals.

I got this movie and watched it with my 10 year-old daughter.  I had heard it was really good and I wanted to bring my girls to see it years ago in the theater but just never got there before it left.  What makes this movie good is the way the main character overcomes his poor reputation and earns his father's respect by being different from all the other Vikings.  What makes this movie great is Toothless, the adorable dragon who joins the main character and helps his accomplish all of the aforementioned success.  The plot is simple but engaging.  The characters are a mixed bag of predictable and likeable.  There is action/violence but nothing horrifying.  It's a good movie for young kids and tween or early teen girls because of the cuteness.  The interaction with the dragons is really entertaining.  I have nothing bad to say about this movie, so it deserves my 5 stars.

Like many of us, I have been a fan of DreamWorks titles ever since Antz. DreamWorks Animation, in my opinion, has always been ahead of the game as far as animated film studios go.

When How to Train Your Dragon came out though, it certainly showed DreamWorks at their best. Why? Because this movie delivery absolutely everything that you would want in an animated family film:

-A worthy plot and story? Check
-Comedy? Check
-Worthy, likeable heroes? Check
-Interesting Antagonist? Check
-Good pacing? Indeed
-Satisfactory ending? More than so
-Good visuals, effects? C'mon, this is DreamWorks we're talking about here.

I haven't read the books by the same title, so I can't compare the movie to them, and I also did not see the film in 3-D so I can't address that aspect.

What I can say is that on its own, and in a simple 2D environment, I felt this film was entertaining and inspiring. I think it can be appealing to both adults and children. However, I do have a few questions which I will point out below.

Plot:

The plot is not something new, it's basically a story about overcoming misunderstanding and prejudice, coupled with parents and kids not listening to each other. We've seen that before, treated many different ways. The film tends to lean more to the kid's side of the issue.  Kids are the main audience, so that makes sense.

I won't belabor the plot points or the message the movie makes, it is better to catch them and decide for yourself (especially if you are a parent). Everyone will have a different take on these. Personally, it resonated with me and gave me reason to consider how I interact with those in my world.

Animation/Character Look:

It's not the standard stuff one would expect from Dreamworks, a-la "Shrek" and "Toy Story".

The CGI characters are exaggerated in their appearance, making them more like a traditional cartoon. This, I think, adds to the fantasy aspect of the film and may be more familiar to the kid audience than the adult one, with a question.

The kids in the movie are pretty much scrawny and look undernourished, yet the adults are so over inflated that they look distorted and in serious need of a diet. Not sure why they chose to differentiate the two groups visually so much. But they do work as characters thanks to the good script and the voice actors, as well as the animators, who do an excellent job.

Another question is that although this is a movie about vikings, the adults speak in a Scottish accent, and the kids (including the hero and heroine) speak like Americans. I have no idea why they chose to do this.

Animals:

The dragons are of course the stars of the film, and here we see creature design unlike anything one might expect.

Toothless, the "hero dragon" looks more like a large black cat than a dragon. This of course adds a curious appeal.

Cats are wonderfully mysterious creatures, with hugely expressive eyes and ears. Toothless also has large expressive cat like eyes and ears, and no real horns to speak of.

There is a lot of superstition about black cats (as a cat lover, I find that black cats are some of the most endearing members of the species) and an undertone in this movie may have been to make Toothless so black cat-like to underscore the danger of blindly following superstitious feelings, or of taking things at face value, when the true value lies underneath, as it does with Toothless and his loving heart.

The other dragons are of all shapes and sizes and do not look like anything in traditional Western or Asian dragon art. Sure, they have spikes and horns and some incredibly long teeth. Their body style and sinewy shapes are graceful and elegant as well as fantastic. I found them fascinating, although it took two viewings of the movie to catch the incredible detail the designers and animators  put into them. They remind me of some of the characters in some 1950's educational Disney movies -- the ones about outer space and how life evolved on Earth (I think UPA had something to do with those old cartoons). Nevertheless, I felt as dragons they were very original and in many ways endearing, sometimes in a silly way.

Scenery:

It's just plain beautiful. They did such a good job with the forest scenes and even the interiors of the viking homes. Nice job, a treat for the eyes.

Music:

Very nice and appropriate "epic/fantasy" style music that supports the story very well. None of the themes are so large as to be truly memorable, (unlike "Star Wars", where so many themes stand out on their own), but it does the job of supporting the action and story very well and quite seamlessly.

Flying Sequences:

If you're going to have flying anything in a movie (let alone dragons) you've got to have great aerobatic flying sequences. This film has them with much of the exciting flavor of a WWII aerial dog fight or a camera set up on a roller coaster. At times the flying is sweeping and acrobatic, at other times, majestic. It's all fantasy of course, so much of the impossible stunts work because the film never tries to suggest anything is reality. This is a fantasy flight of fancy all the way through. Quite a lot of fun.

Emotions:

A good story can tug at the heart strings, but it has to be careful not to overdo it. This approach has been a staple of Disney movies throughout and this film shares that legacy. The difficult relations between Hiccup (the hero) and his father are touching, the exuberance of Hiccup as he flies on the back of Toothless, the touching way Toothless treats Hiccup and many more scenes are very emotional, but not overly so. There is appropriate tension and suspense during the fighting scenes.

Conclusion:

I give this movie 5 stars because it is everything a fantasy adventure is supposed to be, done in fine style. Although it is a 21st century film, it follows the legacy of fine fantasy films from the 1950's and 60's. It's not a blockbuster by any means, neither is it a waste of time.

It's a fun and diverting couple of hours and it may give some members of the audience (adults mostly) pause for thought.

I think it is definitely worth a rental -- for the animation and the story. Can't say if the discs are worth it, or how the 3-D works out however.

I have recently got obsessed with How to Train Your Dragon. Why you might ask? Well because it is the most fantastic, amazing, brilliant movie I have ever seen. Why? Well first of all the music is perfect, always capturing the moment perfectly. Second, the story it just amazing. I don't want to give anything away, so just watch and you will see why. Third, the voice acting is fantastic. Jay Baruchel plays Hiccup the main character, and America Ferrera plays the love interest Astrid. Forth and final reason why this movie is fantastic, amazing, and brilliant is that the visuals are amazing. The animation looks nothing like you have seen before. You can see every little freckle on Hiccups face, even a scar or two. Most people would think of How to Train Your Dragon as a kids movie. Well I don't think so and so does Dreamworks. Dreamworks has said many times it is not intended to be a kids movie more of a teen and adult flick. You will notice if you ask a kid about the movie he saw and does not remember it. Why, because they seen so many other movies that are more kid like that this one slips their mind. Most of the fans are teens and adults, but that doesn't mean a kid would not like it, just that teens and adults will appreciate it more. This movie deserves a 6 out of 5, but Amazon won't let me give it that rating. I say rent it and see if you like. If you have a 3D TV watch in 3D because the 3D also looks fantastic.

Got this for my daughter and she loves it but its good enough that mom and dad will sit and watch as well which says a lot because mom is not a fan of animated movies. Mom has stated that when it comes to kids movies Dad will be taking our daughter to the movies. lol
The movie "How to Train Your Dragon" is probably one of the greatest films I have ever seen, it is without a doubt a future classic.

In the spirit of Enemy Mine, two soldiers locked in battle soon discover that they share more in common than their leaders would seek to understand. The love story that follows will make you laugh, cry, and reconsider your long-held  beliefs regarding good and evil.

This little gem has turned out to be my favorite of all cartoons (and I grew up during the Disney haydays). This is a great story for all ages.
