My 4 and 6 year old love this movie and watch it again and again. This package contains both a blu-ray disc and a DVD: good for when you are on the road and do not have a blu-ray player. The blu-ray image quality is amazing. The bonus materials include the 'Legend of the Boneknapper' which the kids love too.
This was great, very entertaining, it flowed very well, hilarious and a good story besides. I loved it. My favorite quote was "the only thing tougher and more tasteless than the food is the people"

The movie is just amazing. I can't spoil anything but it is worth collecting. The pace of story keeps me interested from start to the end. Never had a low moment. Even though you are an adult, you can't miss this.

I just recently entered the world of Blu-ray and I picked this movie as my first disc. I was not disappointed! The movie itself is amazing with stunning visuals, great humor, and real adventure (not to mention a powerful score by John Powell).The movie on blu-ray looks absolutely stunning. The animated water looks so real, as if the drawings were placed on photographs. Not only am I very pleased with the quality of the movie, but this blu-ray disc is confirmation that I'll never go back to standard definition. If you haven't purchased a blu-ray player, this movie is a great reason to experience hi-def movie watching.

I have no trouble highly recommending this movie to adults and children. I could not rate it a 5, so I had to give it a 4, though a 4 1/2 was more accurate. I will own this. And Scotch accents are what all vikings had, don't you know? Or at least, this was the available, since not many Vikings are plying the waters these days.
Amazing animation.  Not the same everyday animated hero.  Fun for both adults and kids.  I did not think I would enjoy.  I misjudged this movie by its title.  We all enjoyed.

My kids and I, (ages 6, 11 and "I won't share mine") saw this in the theater when it first came out. We loved it then and after watching it again in blu-ray it was just as enjoyable.

The characters are lovable, fun and quirky. The storyline is pure Dreamworks storytelling and the graphics are phenomenal.

I really like the unassuming lead characters that Dreamworks has been creating. They are very likable and hiccup is a true sweetheart (even though he is a viking!).

This is one that I don't mind watching over again and again because the flying scenes in particular are spectacular.

This set, with the blu-ray and DVD are perfect for us because we have a blu-ray player but we also have portable DVD players for travel.

If you are looking for a great family movie this holiday season, this is a great way to go.

The animation was amazing, the action scenes were exciting, and the plot was fresh and enjoyable. Good family fun. Kids will love it, and there is plenty for adults to enjoy as well. Saw it in the theater in IMAX and just watched it for the first time at home in HD on the home theater. Both experiences were excellent, but completely different. In IMAX, you are so immersed in  movie, with things going on all around you, that you can miss how beautifully animated this film is. If you are like me, and saw it previously in 3D, then watch it again for the first time. Highly recommend this movie.
I enjoyed watching it in 3D at the theater so much, I could hardly wait for the BD release. It's great fun and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys fantasy and animation.

This movie is wonderful! For my daughter who loves Dragons, it will probably make kids think that Dragons are not as bad as they look. Most of the movies of Dragons are more related to horrible beasts that like to attack each other and participate in huge wars, if you're expecting that kind of thing, this movie is not for you. Is wonderful to see a movie in which you can see Dragons as wonderful and noble creatures they really are.
Also, the animation is amazing! We're Disney fans and this is the only Dreamworks movie we have, it really is on equal quality or more than any Pixar one you have seen, but he story is what makes is so different from other Dreamworks movies.
After watching this movie 3 times on the theater, my daughter started reading all the books, and she is almost done with all of Hiccup's misadventures that we also recommend. The story on the books is different but all of them have the same thing as the movie: adventure, imagination, and a good lesson on how to be a great Hero, the hard way :)
Most probably our opinions are similar to those of most of the people that liked this movie, but if you get it, it will not disappoint any kid at home (and some adults either), is adventurous, imaginative, exciting, lovely and simply THE BEST MOVIE OF THE YEAR!
I forgot, the legend of the boneknapper dragon is really funny! Short, but really really funny!

Wanted to get this for my little girl and it was 24.99 everywhere I looked.  I found it on Amazon for 17.99 w/free sh/handling.  I LOVE Amazon, I get better deals and my packages are here within 2 days even with the free shipping.
Since it was naught as a Christmas present, I haven't been able to review the movie's quality, but it did come on time and in seemingly good condition.

Great movie. Sure, it was made for kids, but there's plenty for adults to enjoy as well. If you're into fantasy and sci-fi, you'll like it too.  Oh, yeah, and the animation is awesome!

Ok, sure - Some of the Vikings had Scotch accents... and some had no accents at all.  There were some inconsistencies in plot as well.  However, details aside, the movie was enjoyable.

We saw this twice in the theater, both times in 3-D, and both times, my 4 year old son kept taking off his 3-D glasses because he was scared in the opening fighting scene. He likes the movie much better "when it stays in the TV and doesn't come out at you."

This is a great movie. He and his 6 year-old sister just love it.
My wife and I enjoyed this very much, it's an excellent family movie night movie. The dragon flight scenes are great.

I first heard about this film from my coworkers with kids, who were really surprised at how much they liked the movie when they took their kids. I ended up seeing it because my sister, who works in child care, tries to watch all the popular kids movies so she knows what the kids are talking about when they talk about them. She rented the dvd one evening and, since I was pretty bored, I started watching it.

The introduction had me hooked (growing up in Wisconsin, Hiccup's description of the Island of Burke sounded like "Home Sweet Home"), and, five minutes in, I knew I loved the movie. That was before we even saw Toothless.

The story (mild spoilers) follows Hiccup, a young, nerdy Viking as he proves himself to his fellow Vikings -- and the Dragons. The outline of the story really sounds like it could be just about any other teen story out there, but this movie stands heads-and-shoulders above the rest for a combination of reasons. First of all, the characters are great. Hiccup is not just your average annoying, whiny teen-goof-who-must-prove-himself (or, worse, an annoying, whiny teen-nongoof-who-fancies-him/herself-a-goof-who-must-prove-him/herself, ala Bella from Twilight). Instead of whining or denying his shortcomings, he tries to combat them. Ok, so he can't lift heavy hammers or pop off a dragon's head with his hands...but he eagerly runs into battle with his "cannon" to shoot what he can't. No one believes that he took down a dragon; does he throw a temper tantrum or sulk for hours? No, he tries to find the dragon and bring back proof. He's harder on himself than he should be (like, considering himself a coward because he won't kill a defenseless, bound animal), but he's judging himself by his community's standards; and he acknowledges his shortcomings and tries to figure out how to go on despite them. A character that could have come out very cliche, but didn't.
Toothless is...hilarious! The animators * had * to know animals, because they made the actions and expressions of this dragon so believable it's uncanny! He had a very likable "personality" (Dragon-ality?), and was a perfect "pet". The scenes where Hiccup and Toothless get to know each other are incredible...there was so much potential for this to end up cheesy or otherwise to go wrong, but it was all great stuff. Toothless is my favorite character in the whole movie, but I love Hiccup too (followed by the twins).
Astrid, Rough and Tough, Fishlegs, Snotlout (?), Stoic, Gobber, etc. were also fantastic. They all had their own personalities -- and, again, so much potential to go wrong if done wrong...but were instead great -- and part to play in the story.
The voice acting was superb. Hiccup's voice was outrageously good...the twins were absolutely convincing nerds and troublemakers...Astrid was strong but not obnoxious...etc., etc. The voice actors really were crucial here...any of the lines that are hilarious in this film could have been awful if the wrong voice actor attempted them.
The animation was great as well. Watching the final fight scene, I found myself thinking, "Wow, that would be an EPIC battle to witness." And the animators got "body language" down quite well...like the "now we finally have something to talk about" scene. You could feel Stoic's anticipation for the good stories his boy would share.

Another thing I loved about this movie was that, despite the fact that the story was, in essence, a "lesson" story (the Vikings and dragons had misunderstood one another, and ended up "BFF"; the nerdy kid ended up a hero -- and disabled as well [a nice tribute, I think, particularly when we have wounded veterans coming home every day]), it wasn't "preachy" at all. So, kids could take good lessons from the story, but it wasn't a "teaching" movie.
And, as an adult, I loved it. It's one of the best movies to come out in a long time, IMHO. I don't have kids, but I bought this movie anyway. :P

For me, this was by far the best of the 3-D animated films to reach the big screen this year.  Not much is lost in the hi-def 2-D version now available. There are sweeping vistas, believable characters and a majestic sense of flying with the dragons.

The story is simple. Hiccup, a young Viking, defies tradition by befriending a deadly foe, a ferocious dragon he calls Toothless.  Together they must fight tradition and find a way to save both their worlds.

Superbly designed in all aspects -- the characters, the world and the story come together to create a wondrously entertaining diversion for all ages.  I don't say that loosely.

This is truly one of THE best family movies in years.  The characters are charming and funny; the story is engaging; unlike many films made primarily for kids, this one neither talks down to the children nor tries too hard to keep the adults' interest.  Of course my 11-year-old who has read all of Ms. Cowell's books points out the many differences in the movie, but even he loved this delightful film adaptation.  This is truly the kind of movie everyone needs in their home library, because you can watch it over and over and it never gets old.
I love this movie and I also like it that you buy the blue-ray and the dvd in one pack
Adventurous minds of all ages will like this movie.  From the beginning voice-over to the"Let's all be Friends" conclusion, this is a fun rude.
We watched the original dvd version from Netflix about 5 times so Buying it on Blu Ray for the kids for Christmas seemed like a perfect idea!

This is a movie that celebrates intelligence, flexibility, empathy and the ability to see several different points of view.

I'm not going to say anything more about it than that, but it beats the hell out of several other "fantasy" movies I could mention.  It's also PG rated (no-one human dies and there is minimal smooching) so it is good for kids as well.
The movie is great for adults and kids, plus the bonus disc is full of extras.  Worth every penny...

Loved the movie!  Not sure if this is ok for 3 yr olds.  This film would be for 5 yr olds and up.

Story is very cute ..
I absolutely love this movie! It's awesome! The special effects, the comedy, the romance, everything is awesome! This is one of my favorite movies.
A very heartwarming tale of bridging gaps created by lack of deeper insight. It's also a story of following your heart, even if it means going against all odds.

This is a fabulous movie for adults and children alike. I am very careful about what movies I let my young kids watch because I know they will want them played again and again and they have to be bearable for us adults. This is definitely true for How to Train your Dragon. I think this movie really teaches kids to think outside the box and that its OK to be different which are great messages for kids alongside top notch story telling.

The bonus short movie was just as interesting as the main movie although much shorter than the full movie.

Otherwise you are going to have to pay for it off eBay and you better bring your bag-o-cash with you. If you want 3D I suggest you wait until it is released in 3D off the retail shelves. I will definitely buy the 3D version but it makes me mad.
One of the best movies I've ever seen.  and the DVD is great.  can watch it over and over again.  you should get it.

I originally saw the movie at the theater, where you get to enjoy the images of flight much more. But it is still great fun on the big screen at home. (:-)) I have friends (adults) that did NOT use to go view animated films at the movies (no kids). But I like to, and this movie and Up! have convinced them of the wonderful world of animation and its capability to carry the emotional content. The animation excels on the breathtaking backgrounds, specially during flight scenes. The story seems directed to the early teen, feeling awkward in his world and discovering girls (viking girls, lol) for the first time. I also had a chance to view the movie with my brother and my nephews and niece (ages 8 to 16) and they ALL loved it.

The movie itself is quite well done and should be popular for years to come.  The bonus disk, however, I found very disappointing.  The story and the animation for the extra story were not nearly the same quality as the title film.  The bonus story was also very short.  I wish I had saved a few dollars and just bought the single movie disk.  Had I bought the single disk, I would have given it a five-star rating, but the disappointing second disk lowered my overall rating.

1. Will this still be a great movie in 10 years? Make it 20 -- it's an instant classic. A coming of age story that can be translated into any language and someone will watch and relate.

2. There are no scenes that make my toddler run to grab my leg; no treacherous lying plotting homicidal maniacs like in many of the Disney "princess" movies (didn't realize how dark some of the scenes were in those movies until I had a kiddo).

3. If you're a dog/cat/exotic parrot lover -- I think you'll find things to laugh at with the dragon scenes.

I first saw this movie while deployed and loved it.  I knew I had to get the DVD for my son.  After seeing it for the first time, that's all I hear about.  Dragons, dragons, and more dragons.  He loves it as much as I did.
My 18 year old was talking to my 12 year old and told him this is 'like his favorite movie". It will be watched again and again and it's still great!

The animation is excellent, but the story is the really surprising part. It is amazing! This is destined to be a classic. It's less predictable than the average animated family film, and the acting really helps flesh out the characters. It is one of my favorites!

I mean really...

Ya got yer dragons, yer mayhem, comedy that will even make adults laugh and a little kid dancing gleefully in front of the TV/DVD player, repeating the movie word for word.

The only think that irked me was that they actually showed the "bonus" disk episode on Primetime TV the day before the release of the actual movie. so we'd seen it already. That was slick... Ergh!

I don't CARE that the movie was different than the books. Name me one movie made from a book that stayed true to the original author. See? So get over it.

What's important is that my child loved it and it may even inspire him to want to read the books.

I give it two thumbs up...

My review isn't going to be that long, but I will get straight to the point. I have never loved a animated movie this much, enough to be able to watch it countless times within a two week span, and I am 21 and know great animated movies. I grew up up on Aladdin, Lion King, Beauty and the Beast( probably my all time favorite animated movie). This movie greatly rivals alot of the movies I just mentioned in terms of keeping your attention, and just being an amazing movie. How to train your dragon is a great movie, I literally try and get every friend I have to watch this movie. I highly recommend this movie to any and everybody you will not regret it. My buddy who downloaded this movie said that he liked it so much he is going to go out and buy it. I at first was like sure, it can't be that good. Boy was I wrong I am catching myself watching multiple times not getting bored not once, and I am also considering on going out and buying it on Blu Ray DVD. A 5 out of 5 in my book.

good thing the first disk is a good movie

bought this for my nieces and nephew, after taking them to see it on the big screen they asked how long till it would be on DVD. it is a great movie and they loved the extra story that came with it.

How to train your dragon is hands down the best CG animated movie I've seen since The Incredibles. I have been disappointed by Pixar for the last few years feeling most of their stuff is way overrated. Dreamworks has been a mixed bag too. Flushed Away was great, Kung Fu Panda was fun, and Bee movie was cute as well. But Up and Ratatoullie were let downs for me and Cars and Wall E were just ok IMO. HTTYD is simply awesome. If you have a blue ray player the picture looks awsome and the sound is great.  I higly recomed this movie for all ages.

This movie is original and fun, endearing and hilarious.  It is my family's new favorite! I recommend this to everyone with children between 5 and 10 (and over 30 too).

Great characters, engaging story, and a thought-provoking conclusion makes this the best movie I've seen so far this year (granted I have not seen a lot this year so far). This movie proves that the future of 3D cinema largely depend on the ability of filmmakers to deliver the goods, and not in allowing technology to lead its path (Clash of the Titans, I'm looking at you).

The loss of a star is due to Amazon's ability to get us the movie in a timely basis (see last paragraph).

Otherwise this is a 5 star DVD.  Great movie and a nice story.  When it was in the theatre, my (then 6-year old) son managed to get himself taken to this movie 3 times by different members of the family.  He loves it.  Somehow we heard that Wal-Mart had t-shirts, at the time, but by the time we got there, we were able to only get one of the last ones.  It seems that for as little as this movie gets advertised, it still has some hard-core fans.
The Boneknapper video is pretty good, but fairly short (15-min (?)). We haven't had time to go through all of the features, but have been pleased thus far.

One disappointing thing was that Amazon was not able to pre-ship the DVD before the release.  The release was on a Friday, so while we could have just gone down to Meijer and bought the movie for the weekend, my son had to wait until the following week because I had pre-purchased the movie for his birthday in September.  Ultimately, this made it a negative thing to have pre-ordered the movie.

Despite the impressive animation effects, plot development was incoherent and thematically diffuse. Some day someone will match the technical wizardry with a logical and consistent story-line, resulting in a production truly worthy of five stars. By the way, why were all the Vikings speaking with Scotch accents?

The movie itself I loved. I'd seen the film in theaters and just had to have it, so I bought the 2 disc combo pack; I now regret it.
I was under the impression that the second disc was bonus materials and a second short film by Dreamworks. Instead I spent more time then I'd like to say just trying to find the menu on the second disc and finally found no second film and some really weak bonus features.

I'm left with a second disc of no value. I recommend that the 2 disc combo be avoided for this film. Don't get me wrong I loved the movie, just stick to the single disc. This second disc isn't worth the extra money.
Great movie for all ages!  It's amazing how they can give dragons emotions without them speaking, which is a refreshing change. The extras are a hoot!
What a wonderful movie. It is the best animated movie in years! We were absolutely amazed.

Few animated movies can accomplish what How To Train Your Dragon does. The film appreciates a broad audience and includes humor for the grandchild to grandparent. The films central characters have real personality and come alive through the film. You easily forget that they are computer generated.  The graphics are amazing but seem slightly dated when compared to new features such as megamind...

The movie "How to train your Dragon" is great. We love it.  It's up there with Finding Nemo and Surf's Up for us.  The dvd plays great -except when you turn it off and back on it's impossible to get it to play from the beginning-maybe just my dvd player?

HOWEVER.  This is the double disc version. The 2 pack.  Where you think you're getting another movie for free.  Another dragon movie.  NOT.

I just tried to play the extra feature and put the disk in my dvd player. Nothing happened.  Then I waited. And waited. Then I hit "menu." Finally I hit the right button I guess, and a menu popped up.

Nothing was highlited and I couldn't scroll through the options. I never got it to play. And the think almost broke my dvd player. After getting the disk out- it was just acting too funky- it wouldn't turn back on.

Finally after I unplugged everything and plugged it back in, I was able to get my dvd player to work again.

Let me say, I am not pleased.  If you read the fine print on the 2nd disk you will find out that it is 16 minutes long. Um, seriously?  16 minutes.  That's not even a whole little kids episode on TV.  WTF?!

And if you have a mac, forget about it. It states that it is Microsoft only.  again, WTF?!?

How to Train Your Dragon is an amazing story about a young boy learning more about dragons, and finding out dragons can be allies and not enemies.

The vikings, dragons, storyline, and art are amazing due to a lot of hard work. The Dreamworks Animated Studios did a perfect job with this movie and putting it together like a sculpture full of beauty. My favorite character is Toothless. Toothless is a lovable and storng dragon who reminds me of a Pokemon and Stitch from "Lilo and Stitch". Toothless was also cute and he is one of my favorite movie animals of all time (even if he is a 3D character).

One of my favorite scenes in this movie is where Hiccup comes back for Toothless and both characters draw on the ground. After Hiccup draws Toothless on the ground, Toothless the dragon ended up creating his own drawing (which is in the form of a neat scribble). Before Toothless honors Hiccup with trust, Hiccup was able to dance around Toothless' drawing without stepping on the lines (which would cause Hiccup to get himself harmed if he did it more than three times). This scene was truly original and creative, and I made me tear and feel joyful.

My other favorite scenes involve Toothless flying in the air with Hiccup and Astrid during the afternoon, and Toothless takes on a mean, gigantic dragon near the movie's end.

This movie is a treat for all who like dragons and this is by far Dreamwork Animated Studios' best movie yet. A++

"Thank you for everything, you useful and graceful reptile."
This is a fabulous movie.  Great for both kids and adults.  Humerous and sweet at the same time.  Picture Quality for Blu Ray?  Amazing

I've already written a review of this movie for my university's paper. The Blu-Ray/DVD version is exceptional and the quality is top notch. The movie is essentially unchanged, so here is that review:

"As an SU student, I think it would suffice to say that I don't get out much. That could have been why I was initially skeptical when my sister recommended to me the PG-rated "How to Train Your Dragon." I should have never doubted her. As a reviewer, I could simply join the ranks of countless other movie critiques across the nation and compare HTTYD to "Avatar" or nitpick its uninspired plot, but I am of the impression that would be a bore to you and me both. Instead, I'll be approaching this movie from what I am - a 90s-kid college student. So that we're on the same page, allow me to lay down some context. The young, unlikely hero Hiccup lives on the Viking island of Berk. The village's life is dominated dragon warfare. However, after accidentally capturing his own dragon, Hiccup rescinds from old traditions and attempts to convince his tribe that everything they know about dragons is wrong.

"The most striking aspect of this movie was the dragons. The movie introduces several "species" of dragon, but the star of the show is Hiccup's Night Fury, affectionately named Toothless. Where to start? For starters, I am an Animal Behavior student and found Hiccup's willingness to watch and record behavior before making inferences pretty incredible. In addition, I am a herpetologist, which is to say that I study amphibians and reptiles. The Night Fury species had an interesting body design that was fun to look at, but the most interesting anatomical bit were the flaps on the sides of its head (reminding me of the axolotls, a type of salamander). The suspension of disbelief was so subtle in this movie, I often found myself wondering how the behaviors of the several species would be different in the presence or absence of this or that (common thoughts for my scientific discipline, but only for real things!).

"If one were to suppose dragons could fly, one could also believe that their flight would allow for insanely cool 3D flying sequences. I'm not a huge fan of effects-films, but HTTYD threw in just enough of the computer magic to maintain an immersive and exciting story. The Real D 3D technology being pushed into so many theaters was subtle enough to not be gimmick-y (an event I have been awaiting for so very long). I could be biased, what with my ocular handicap, but the 3D glasses were comfortable enough to wear that I almost forgot I was wearing them as the credits rolled. To complement this great animation the characters, though characature-ish, are on screen for long enough to maintain established and believable personalities. The soundtrack is pretty good, considering we aren't talking about a musical. Memorable songs include "Forbidden Friendship" and "Sticks & Stones," a song by Icelandic lead singer of Sigur Rós, Jónsi.

"Halfway through production of HTTYD, Chris Sanders and Dean DeBlois (the co-directors and writers of Disney's "Lilo & Stitch") took over as co-directors. I couldn't imagine the movie with any other direction. If you grew up when I did, you saw and loved "Lilo & Stitch," and for many of the same reasons, you would love HTTYD. The characters Lilo and Toothless are almost totally replaceable - even their facial structure and expressions are similar. Although DreamWorks Animation has typically been regarded as releasing films that just don't match the Pixar standard, HTTYD makes a fierce game-breaker. It really is that good."
Toothless was the cutest thing he kinda reminded me of a big cat...I cried when I thought him and Hiccup were dead......excellent movie...Thoothless rocks!!!!!!!

DreamWorks Animation delivers another wholehearted dose of top-quality entertainment with the fun-filled animated adventure "How to Train Your Dragon". In the small island of Berk, a scrawny but inventive teenage Viking named Hiccup (Jay Baruchel) hopes of earning the respect of his father (Gerard Butler) and the rest of the village by slaying his first dragon, but when he stumbles upon a frightened and injured beast, he can't bring himself to kill it. Hiccup defies centuries of tradition by befriending the dragon he calls Toothless and learns that he must convince his village the errors of their ways. "How to Train Your Dragon" is an interesting and utterly charming family spectacle from the creators of "Shrek" and "Kung Fu Panda". Though the story is pretty straightforward, the animated film is a heartfelt mix of adventure and comedy. The characters are amusing and well developed. The computer animation is certainly stunning. "How to Train Your Dragon" also stars America Ferrara, Jonah Hill, T.J. Miller, Kristen Wiig, Christopher Mintz-Plasse and Craig Ferguson.

DreamWorks has maintain a solid record with the Blu-ray releases of its computer-generated movies and with "How to Train Your Dragon", the studio continues to bring out some must-have additions to your Blu-ray collection. The animated adventure is presented in 2.35:1 widescreen format. The picture quality is flawless with fabulous detail. The DTS-HD 5.1 audio is truly reference-quality. Though a 3-D copy is not included in this release, the Blu-ray features a DVD copy of the film and great extras like the animated short "Legend of the BoneKnapper Dragon", several behind-the-scenes featurettes (Viking-Sized Cast, The Technical Artistry of Dragon, The Story Behind the Story & How to Draw a Dragon), deleted scenes and a commentary track with directors Chris Sanders and Dean DeBlois, and producer Bonnie Arnold. Overall, "How to Train Your Dragon" scores an "A-".
Is a nice movie. I like that Gerard Buttler didn't impersonate his 300 movie voice here. It does have a Viking touch, but without overdoing it, really nice and sweet.

I usually don't buy animated movies.  There are no kid in our household, but I had to buy this one.  The story line was great, the characters were great and the animation was great.  I loved it and look forward to watching it again.

It seems as if our family spends more time deciding what movie we want to rent than actually *watching* the movie once we decide. But finding this one new to Amazon's video on demand was a no-brainer - and the quickest decision for "movie night" that we've ever made.

We saw this movie multiple times as a family in the theater (never in 3D, because that's just not that important to us) and tonight's viewing was on Amazon's VOD in HD on my Sony Bravia. What a *fantastic* experience (better than the theater!) and the movie is simply one of the best movies our family has seen in a number of years. Incredible story, exciting, funny - and absolutely beautiful. Oh, and the music was perfect. Sweeping, melodic and memorable.

Probably the biggest compliment I could pay this movie was the fact that in no way was it "dumbed down" or formulaic for a family movie. Too many movies of late are too predictable with their obligatory stupid jokes insults. This movie was above that. It was surprising and creative - with a very witty and well-thought-out script.

My only complaint is that the trailer for this movie (at least the one we saw when it was being advertised for the theaters) didn't do it justice. So we didn't initially jump to see it. But we've more than made up for it with the multiple viewings since.

Kudos to Amazon for making this available in HD and in *fantastic* quality.

(for you geeks out there like me, the encoding on this was among the best I've seen in my streaming experience - absolutely stunning, limited artifacts except for some of the solid color scenes). OK, enough geek speak.  :-)

This is a fantastic movie.  It has good character development.  The interaction between the characters is very believable.  The animation is fantastic.  It really almost looks real.  Would love to see a sequel.  I recommend this one for the whole family.

Unfortunately this isn't the 3D Blu-ray version, that version is currently only available via a Panasonic 3D TV starter kit. Do not buy this version, wait for the 3D version to be released later next year, which usually runs $5 or so more. When the family entertainment system is upgraded to 3D the 3D version of this movie will be ready for the new 3D gear and no more money will be wasted buying the same movie in the newer format.
Great characters, good story, lots of funny moments, even had me a little teary at the end.  :)
Amazing original movie! Story is great, animation and effects stunning - so glad its finally on blu-ray! It's a classic!

An few lines from "Our Deepest Fear - Marianne Williamson / A Return to Love"

Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate.
Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure.

Hiccup could not imaging befriending a Vikings' idea of the most dangerous dragon and defeating an even more scarier and very dangerous monster dragon.

The movie has the most interesting characters and very imaginative versions of dragons I have seen in years.

I have to say that when a Dreamworks Animation film is released my hopes aren't high. From my point of view, they aim mostly for cheap laughs with mediocre stories. However, sometimes they do hit the right string and deliver a throughfully entertaining film with great visuals, characters and story. So far, from the 20-plus films that Dreamworks had released since its foundation, I found only five worth seeing and owning (Shrek, Shrek 2, Chicken Run, Wallace & Gromit and Kung Fu Panda). When I walked to a Dreamworks film I never have high hopes like when I enter a Pixar film (all of which are excellent). This year was not the exception and when I saw trailers for How to Train Your Dragon, I never got too much excited about it. All I have to say is that I couldn't be more wrong!!

For the first time, I feel that Dreamworks did a film that can be up there with the Pixar catalogue. I haven't seen such a great film produced by Dreamworks since the first Shrek was released. This movie is an instant classic!!

Instead of aiming for sitcom-esque jokes like most of his films, HTTYD has what all Pixar films have: a wide appeal. This film can be enjoyed by every member of the family and has a good quality humor and most important of all, a heart (a thing that is usually missing from Dreamworks). Add breathtaking visuals, a magnificent score, action, great characters and you have one of the most compelling animated films of all time. I still think Pixar is better and in fact I think Toy Story 3 is better than this one but without a doubt with HTTYD, Dreamworks make a huge step formward and became closer to Pixar (a step that may have gone backwards again with the fourth and hopefully last Shrek). Do I have more confidence in Dreamworks films? Not really, we'll have to see how Megamind and future films stand. But even if is the beginning of a new era for Dreamworks or an isolated success, HTTYD is a masterpiece.

The Blu-Ray transfer is gorgoeus. You can see every detail in the screen, absolutely magnificent. The 5.1 dolby true HD is equally impressive. The are many nice bonus features (including a new short). Most of them are short but they are fun to watch nontheless.

The DVD provided here also looks great for SD but is no match for the BD quality.

How To Train Your Dragon is an excellent film that is completely recommended (even if you don have kids like myself). Congratulations to Dreamworks for showing us that when they want to, they can do great things. Let's hope more films like this one will come in the future from this studio.

I was actually going around to all the "Redbox"s in my town looking for the A Nightmare on Elm Street [Blu-ray] and when none of them had it i just decided to rent this. I ended up keeping it for 4 days and watching it 4 times. I don't care who you are, this movie is amazing. great acting, animation, and story. It starts out like a lot of movies; an underdog struggling to keep up with his peers. He then discovers something that will put him in the history books but it all explodes in his face. I don't want to give anything away, but this is a very emotion-driven movie with some very serious situations. *****!

This is a fun family film. There is plenty of adventure, comedy, and good times. It is an exciting ride from beginning to end, as the viewer follows Hiccup and Toothless. The Bluray version is crisp and vibrant. I would recommend this movie to any animated feature film buff, kid, or kid at heart.

My family and I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  It is sure to be a classic.  It has a good mix of action, adventure, comedy, and age appropriate romance.  However, I would not recommend it for very young children as they might find a few scenes to scary.

Very impressive, Dreamworks. This is, in my opinion, your greatest film to date! Everything, from the animation, to the soundtrack and voice acting, is superbly executed. The only thing I can find to complain about is the lack of a digital copy with the combo pack. A minor complaint, which doesn't take away from the experience of this movie. The extras are just icing on the cake. Thank you, DreamWorks, for creating such an amazing animated film!

I originally got this film from Netflix - have watched it 3 times in the last 2 days.  It is fantastic - not only the animation - but the story and the characters.
It hits you on a deep level.  A good hit for adults as well as children.  We need more people in the world like the main character(s) in this story.  I know I will watch the movie over and over - and will send the DVD to my family in California.  I know they will love it too.  I highly recommend the movie for children and people of all ages.

Personally, I'm always annoyed that almost all 'cartoons' are labeled as 'kids movies'.  This really isn't for younger kids.  For a 4-5 year old, it's pretty scary.

On the other hand, this is still a fantastic movie.  The art is amazing.  I hated the dragons until about halfway through, I just didn't like the funky shapes.  But, they really grew on me and I began to notice all the subtleties of their expressions.

This movie is FUNNY.  I'm 38 and I laughed out loud several times.  My son, probably too young for it, wasn't too interested until the end and then he was cheering with me and my wife.

Dreamworks really does some fantastic stuff and this is one of their best.

The viking genre is a perennial one in Hollywood, with about one major release per year.  Previous releases include Beowulf, Pathfinder, The 13th Warrior among others.  All these previous movies shared one result; bad reviews.  Now Dreamworks takes a stab at the genre with an animated comedy, and scores one of the biggest hits of 2010; How to Train Your Dragon.  Unlike Shrek, Over the Hedge, Antz and Dreamwork's previous animated films, this one focuses primarily on human characters and their relationships, with only one key non-human involved, the dragon Toothless.  And interestingly, Toothless does not talk, which is rare in animated films.  Yet the combination works out.  The movie is funny, the storyline is extremely original, and the characters have depth and create empathy among the audience.  Most of the comedy is either slapstick action comedy involving the dragons, or humorous dialogue between the viking characters; all of which is appropriate for even the youngest children.

I consider this one of the best movies of 2010.  This would have been the best animated film of 2010 if Toy Story 3 was not around.  But since both films came out this year, we might see 2 animated nominations for the Best Picture at the Academy Awards come February.  Both the Blu-Ray and regular DVD come with an additional short film featuring most of the main, human characters from the main movie.  This short film is quite entertaining, though it is pure comedy and lacks some of the heart of the feature film.  There are no additional scenes in the movie, just the standard features that come with a DVD, such as interviews with cast members, and a history of the effort it took to go from book to film.  Overall, worth the time to watch it, and the money to buy this set.

How to Train Your Dragon is great for the whole family.  As with other great stories, every age group will get something different from it.  The story itself is very touching, but it also lends itself to teachable moments.  Each one of us has a "dragon" that we need to train.

I watched the movie about four times in theater, and I loved seeing it every time (and I'm just a poor college student!). The characters, the soundtrack, the animation... It just does everything right and is officially my favorite 3D film. I'm sure there are several reviews that will go into great detail about its greatness, so let me talk a bit about the actual product.

One of the biggest things going for HTTYD is the quality of animation. So, if you thought seeing it in 3d on the big screen looked amazing, getting in Blu-ray is the next best thing (if not equal). They move extremely smooth, the detail of hair and texture of clothing is extremely realistic, yet all the cartoon-styled facial expressions and movement are captured with comical grace. Believe me, there were several scenes where I would honestly have thought they were shot from real life.

The extras in this DVD are fulfilling for both adults and children. For the children, it ranges from viking quizzes, a juke box, and even a 'How to Draw Your Dragon' segment! Meanwhile, the film commentary, detailed behind-the-scenes sections, deleted scenes, and cast interview is definitely interesting for the older range audience. Most of all, there is the short film 'Legend of the Boneknapper Dragon' which is a very light hearted and hilarious animated extra, taking place sometime after the movie. It had me literally laughing out loud several times (Frozen vikings, anyone?). It includes 2d animated parts, which I'm sure many miss having around ever since most kids movies nowadays are 3D/CG'd in some way.

In the end, it really is just worth it. About $20 for top-notch quality and an exclusive extra film for a movie I love to death-- why not?

This is an actual review of the product. I saw the film at the theatre, and bought the disk on the strength of the 3D cinema version. I should add that I've seen EVERY 3D movie as I'm actively involved in developing 3D solutions. A few comments on the film first.

This is one of the best 3D films currently produced. Where others disappoint or add nothing to the viewer's experience, the 3D in this film is used to great effect. Flying sequences do bring out the best in 3D it seems! To-date the only 3D film to rival this one is Avatar (of course). In general animation lends itself to 3D because the creative opportunities are greater. Also, live action Directors seem to have a problem leveraging 3D at present. We need a new generation of Directors, better cameras and processing, and better screenplay before we see 3D achieve its true potential.

But enough of that. At least 17% of the public can't see 3D so lets get to the 2D BluRay disk. First, the 2D disk seems noticeably longer than the 3D version I watched. I don't have figures on this, but the flying sequences seem longer. Maybe not, but subjectively it felt that way. In any case, I enjoyed the second viewing almost as much as the first. This is one of those rare disks that merits many plays. Of course humor and action lend themselves to repeat plays, but what distinguishes this film is the attention to detail and the endearing characters. I won't bother repeating the positive reviews which abound for this film. Just enough to say I adore the dragons, the people... everything about this film is good or great.

The extra material is a bit of a let down. The deleted scenes are storyboards for the most part; I was hoping for some genuine animation. Trawling through the rest of the material, there is a BD-Live connection which was momentarily interesting. It is clear the studios need to work at understanding what the internet savvy user finds entertaining. So overall I was underwhelmed by the extra material - it was worth watching once.

Overall I'd have to say this is a disk I don't regret buying (I subscribe to Netflix) because I know it will get watched time and time again. As an adult this film really works; I would be tempted to say that adults are the primary, target audience. It is that rich an experience. Anyhow, I'm a sucker for films with dragons. Enjoy!

The commercials made it seem more 'kid ish'... I was expecting happy go lucky fun times training dragons.

Its a really good story overall, and well written too... all in a kids movie!

A+

Probably one of the cutest movies I've seen in a long time. It kept my kids' attention the whole time. The movie never drags. It is fun and full of action. My kids are 8 and 5 so they did okay with the (mildly) scary parts. Overall, a definite owner. Only down side is there isn't a digital copy of the movie. :(
Very great movie, nicely, smartly and tastefully done. I watched in in theater and I will buy blu-ray as well. Very enjoyable to both kids and adults.

This one has already has won the persol 3D award in venice with Avatar , and is the best of all Dreamworks movies!!! looks awsome on blu-ray Too!!! The 3D flying scenes in in this movie are in my mind better than Avatar!!!

The ending just BLEW me AWAY. My family and I had watched the first half yesterday, and the rest today. The first half was HILARIOUS, and the second half kept us at the edge of our seats. Romance didn't ruin it and there were absolutely no awkward or cheesy moments between characters or the viewers. The ending has left an impression and inspiration on author me for the rest of my life. Seeing the Prince of Egypt made me love Dreamworks, seeing Planet 51 made me feel it was degrading, but How to Train Your Dragon had made me an AVID AVID fan!!! I thoroughly,  thoroughly recommend it. BUY IT!!!!

Very few movies hit the inspirational side to me and this one did.  Found myself laughing and enjoyed watching this film.  Only thing strange I noticed was that Toothless seemed to be different sizes throughout the movie.  Other than that I think it was darn near perfect.  Someone said the leg scene was too graphic.  Graphic?  Most kids watch A Christmas Carol and the poor boy named Tiny Tim had a wooded leg.  What's the big deal you big sissy?

I wish I could state somewhere easier that I own the DVD and also pick from different versions to chose from when the name is presented.

P.S. The check boxes for already owning a product and relative info need to be better accessible and more information provided such as multiple versions of the same name where available. No one wants to stop what they are doing (shopping etc) to hunt down the box to say they already own something, a different version of the one they are looking at, or to be able to critique it. ...........

I liked this movie a lot I watched it twice in a row and still didn't find anything i didn't like its a laugh a miniute movie plus the short sequal that came with the double pack well not as funny as the first was still quite hellarious. If I were to make a recomendation to anyone interested watch this movie you won't be disappointed.

I didn't get to see this in the theater, but I picked up the BD copy locally.  I love animated movies, one of the reason I went to school for it, and must say this movie was great.  The character designs are exceptional, and animated beautifully.  Watching this on a 50" plasma, the movie quality was stunning.  I think this is my new reference disc to use when I want to show off BD movies and/or HD material.  Easily recommend this one to buy.

I'll keep it short and sweet. How To Train Your Dragon is a fantastic experience. Everybody should watch it at least once.

Great family film :D

"How To Train Your Dragon" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: A Viking teenager named Hiccup lives on the island of Berk, where fighting dragons is a way of life. The teen's smarts and offbeat sense of humor don't sit too well with his tribe or its chief... who just happens to be Hiccup's father. However, when Hiccup is included in Dragon Training with the other Viking teens, he sees his chance to prove he has what it takes to be a fighter. But when he encounters (and ultimately befriends) an injured dragon, his world is flipped upside down, and what started out as Hiccup's one shot to prove himself turns into an opportunity to set a new course for the future of the entire tribe.

The voice cast led by Jay Baruchel (as Hiccup) & Gerard Butler (as Stoick) is excellent! The directing by Chris Sanders (he also did the stories to "Beauty And The Beast" (1991), "Aladdin" (1992) & "The Lion King" (1994, also did the production design) & Dean DeBlois (both of them also wrote & directed "Lilo & Stitch" (2002) is brilliant! The screenplay (based on the novel by Cressida Cowell) by Sanders, DeBlois & William Davies (who also did the story & screenplay to "Twins" (1988) & the screenplay to "Flushed Away" (2006) is brilliant!

The music by John Powell (who also did the music, recently to "Green Zone" (2010), "Knight & Day" (2010) & the upcoming "Fair Game" (2010), he also doing the music to the upcoming "Rio" (2011) is brilliant! The film editing by Maryann Brandon (who also did the film editing to "Mission: Impossible III" (2006), "Star Trek" (2009), the upcoming "Gulliver's Travels" (2010) & "Super 8" (2011) & Darren T. Holmes (who also did the film editing to "The Iron Giant" (1999), "Lilo & Stitch" & "Ratatouille" (2007) is excellent! The production design by Kathy Altieri (who also did the production design to "Spirit: Stallion Of The Cimarron" (2002), "Over The Hedge" (2006), she also did the art direction to "The Prince Of Egypt" (1998) is brilliant! The art direction by Pierre-Olivier Vincent (who also did the art direction to "Flushed Away") is brilliant!

This is a fun and entertaining animated film that keeps you entertained and amazed. This is a well-made and well-crafted film that is different and interesting than most animated films out there. This is one of the best efforts for Dreamworks, outside of the Shrek movies, ever. This is also one of the best films of the year.

...because I want one! How to Train your Dragon is an awesome movie for kids and adults alike. Not only is it visually amazing, the cast is fantastic(Jay Baruchel as Hiccup, Gerard Butler as Stoick, Jonah Hill as Snotlout, Craig Ferguson as Gobber, and America Ferrara as Astrid). But awesome cast aside, in this movie, even the dragons had personality!

The story is simple. Hiccup, a scrawny Viking boy who can't seem to fit in, unknowingly shoots down and injures a feared Night Fury dragon. The dragon has lost part of his tail wing, and can't fly. However the compassionate Hiccup can't bring himself to kill it. Instead Hiccup befriends the dragon, naming him Toothless, and invents a contraption that allows Toothless to finally fly free. Hiccup's friendship with Toothless helps him to view dragons and his world differently, and to challenge everything that he's been taught.

How to Train Your Dragon is a heartwarming story of trust and friendship, and carving new paths for yourself even when you've been trained to follow old ones. There are lots of laughs and great dialogue, and I have to admit there were one or two emotional moments too. Great film for grown-ups and kids. I saw it in 3D in IMAX, and I bought the DVD which I watched again yesterday. It was just as good as I remembered. My kids loved it too. You can't go wrong with this one.

Vikings are by all accounts burly, hairy, looming, and fierce, and that's probably just the womenfolk. Hiccup, the movie's sometime narrator, isn't your average tough and brawly Viking. Hiccup happens to be a hapless, noodly-figured, often scorned Viking teenager, and that his father is the intimidating village chief is maybe the sole reason why he isn't kicked more to the curb. Hiccup spends most of his days trying to prove himself to the warrior community. He only keeps on embarrassing himself. He's often relegated to the smithy, indoors and safe as the blacksmith's lowly apprentice.

Hiccup's village sits on a desolate island, and it's a bleak living, made even more arduous by frequent encroachments of ravaging, fire-breathing dragons. Hundreds of years have seen these battle-craving Vikings hunting down these dragons, and Hiccup is expected to step into this manly habit. Except that Hiccup, an outsider and more introspective than most, will sort of accidentally topsy turvy that age-old tradition. But that's only if he makes it thru dragon slaying school. And if he survives his efforts to befriend the elusive Night Fury dragon.

DreamWorks Animation still lags behind Pixar, but HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON goes a ways in garnering street cred for DreamWorks. It's real easy to get behind the story, its themes and philosophies, and the likable central character. The best things - or, rather, my favorite bits - about this film all have to do with Hiccup hanging out with his dragon and incidentally picking up invaluable insights in dealing with dragons. Toothless the Night Fury dragon is awesome and wonderfully expressive. Whenever Toothless springs into action, the film pulses with an exhilarating sense of adventure. These moments are when we're reminded that Toothless may be adorable but he's still very much a formidable presence. The message of tolerance and open-mindedness is naturally integrated into the story, so thankfully this doesn't at all feel like one of those very special Blossom episodes.

The animation is really excellent, with the CG artists opting for more playful, more exaggerated renditions of the human characters and the dragons. The most realistically rendered elements turn out to be the atmospheric land-, sea-, and skyscapes. The dragon flights in this film are as breathtaking as those we saw in AVATAR. It makes me wish I'd seen this in 3D. I don't know why these Vikings have burry Scottish accents, but it does give us a chance to listen to the always funny Craig Ferguson (Gobber), so it's all good. Gerard Butler, who plays Hiccup's bullish father, channels his roaring persona from 300.

So I've got the 2-DVD set. Disc 1 has the feature presentation and the following bonus stuff:

- Audio commentary with Filmmakers Chris Sanders, Dean DeBlois, and Bonnie Arnold

- "Viking-Sized Cast" has interviews with the voice actors (00:11:44 minutes long)

- "The Technical Artistry of HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON" - a focus on the film's state-of-the-art CG technology (00:10:13)

- "Get Your Game On" previews the HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON and KUNG FU PANDA WORLD video games

- Trailers to SHREK FOREVER AFTER, THE PENGUINS OF MADAGASCAR, THE LAST AIRBENDER, and the upcoming MEGAMIND

- The trailer to and a Behind the Scenes segment on SHREK THE MUSICAL

The second DVD offers the fun animated short, LEGEND OF THE BONEKNAPPER DRAGON. It runs at around 16 minutes long. Taking place some time after the events in the film, this one tells of how the blacksmith Gobber, Hiccup and his young Viking friends embark on a quest across the icy seas for the mythical Boneknapper dragon. But they end up stranded on a barren rock formation. This short also features moments of old school 2D animation (whenever Gobber is flashing back to one of his rather far-fetched stories). My biggest beef with this short: Toothless is barely in this one.

Bonus material for this second DVD:

- 3 Deleted Scenes from the feature film, done in rough storyboard sketches, with intros from Director/Co-Writer Dean DeBlois (total running time: 00:07:34 minutes)

- "The Story Behind the Story" presents an interview with HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON author Cressida Cowell (00:07:40 minutes)

- ""Racing for the Gold" is a fun, quick, animated peek into four categories within the Viking Winter Games (bobsledding, speed skating, ski jumping, and snowboarding) and also the medal ceremony for that greatest of Viking sports, Dragon Training (the top medal is made out of ham)

- Animator Gabe Hordos instructs on "How to Draw Toothless" (00:10:57)

- "Take the Viking Personality Test" - Take a multiple-choice survey to learn which of the characters in the film you're most like

- "DreamWorks Animation Video Jukebox" allows you to click on songs from previous DreamWorks animated flicks: "I'm a Believer" (SHREK), "I Like To Move It, Move It" (MADAGASCAR), "Everybody Was Kung Fu Fighting" (KUNG FU PANDA), "Rockin' the Suburbs" (OVER THE HEDGE), and "Here Comes the Sun" (BEE MOVIE)

- "Dragon Activity Center" - Insert this DVD into your PC and access the following DVD-ROM activities: "Build Your Own Dragons" (construct a life-size Toothless, a 3D Gronckle, a 3D Terrible Terror, and a 3D Night Fury) and "Viking Zone" (a peek at Viking Accessories, Viking & Dragon Masks, Flashlight Patterns, Growth Chart, Coloring Pages, and Stickers)

I loved this film and saw it 4 times in the theater. I also love the soundtrack from this movie and it's my favorite since the infamous soundtrack from Dragonheart (this link is for the cassette since the cd link oddly has no audio samples to listen to). My mom loved the HTTYD soundtrack when she heard me listening to it (particularly "Forbidden Friendship" and "Romantic Flight"). So I was super excited to watch this movie with her last night. However, I was heartbroken when she declared afterwards that the only thing she liked about the movie was the music. She even said "Toothless" the dragon was downright "evil looking". Me (and everyone else in my family) thought he was simply adorable. She said she hated the vikings in the movie to and couldn't care about any of them. Apparently she thought/hoped this was going to be a movie set in modern times and some kid would just find a dragon out in the woods one day. She said this film did not even come close to dethroning "Finding Nemo" and "Monsters Inc." as her favorite family cartoon movies. So I guess I can't say it's a guarantee that everyone will love this (even though before last night, I would have definitely believed that). Anyway, there are enough reviews on this fantastic movie to go around explaining how great it is. However, I will say that the bonus "Legend Of The Boneknapper Dragon" dvd was nothing I would miss if I hadn't gotten it for only $1 extra. The film makers know "Toothless" was the main draw to this franchise, so they decided to almost entirely leave him out of this (roughly) 13 minute short film. I am assuming they don't want people to get worn out on "Toothless" before the HTTYD sequel in 2013. He is on screen only about 5 seconds, which is far too short in my opinion. Really, the only reason to see this short film is to see what the "Boneknapper" dragon looks like. Apart from that, don't be afraid that you are missing much, because you are not. Still, if you're a collector like I am, it doesn't hurt to have it since it's only an extra buck (which is really all it is worth).

I very rarely review a movie ---for anyone. This one is an exception. I saw "How to Train Your Dragon" in 3D in the theaters. I was very impressed. A simple story yet carried out with eaceptional grace. There were no bumps, no long drawn out sub plots, just a story about a lonely boy and his dreams.

The animation was beyond superb. Dreamworks has captured CGI with all the aplomb that once belonged solely to ILM. This is why I bought Blu-Ray. It captures the art so well. Audio supports the story line and never overwhelms it.

For those adults who don't like "cartoons", this isn't one. Try it out. You'll be very pleasantly surprised.

I am really surprised that HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON did not do better in the theatres.  My husband, 13 and 5 year old daughters, and I selected this movie for family movie night a few weeks ago, and we all liked it very much.  HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON is a sweet, adorable movie, beautifully rendered, with a kind-hearted messages.

DreamWorks really did a nice job with HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON.  In HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON, we meet Hiccup, the son of a Viking chief.  Hiccup is, well, different that the other Viking kids; he is skinny, smart, and not particularly interesting in killing things.  Unfortunately, their village is constantly under attack by dragons, and all children must learn to become dragon hunters.  Hiccup does try to kill dragons, but he always fails, often times making things worse for his village.  Finally, through a stroke of pure luck, Hiccup manages to bring down a dreaded Night Fury dragon; but, of course, no one sees it happen.  Not even his father believes his story.  Tenderhearted Hiccup cannot bring himself to kill the dragon, who he names Toothless.  Instead the two bond and form a fast friendship, Hiccup learns how to tame dragons without killing them, and in the end, saves his village and his people from an even worse threat.

The plot of HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON is story we have all heard before, countless times, but, quite frankly, we didn't care at all.  The animation is gorgeous, the voice actors are quite talented, and the tale is very charmingly told.  My 5 year old loved it (and wants repeated viewings), the 13 year old declared it okay (which at this age is EXTREMELY high praise), and my husband and I enjoyed ourselves.  The messages are clear and kid appropriate:  1. Don't do things just because they've always been done that way.  2.  Think for yourself.  3.  Get to know your enemy.  If you can't remember why you are fighting, it might be time to stop.

HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON is good family entertainment, perfect for a quiet evening at home.  My kids now want pet dragons.  Hmm...  I wonder if I can fit 2 dragons in the backyard...

When I first went to go see How to Train your Dragon in theaters, I was left speechless and didn't even realize I was the last one left sitting when I finally broke out of the trance and looked around!

Definitely one of the best films of the year, and my personal favorite movie of all time! Whether your a child or an adult, you will love this movie- guaranteed!
Wonderful movie - it started out a little average, but somewhere in the middle I fell totally in love with it - one of the best kids movies in a long time.

This movie is easily my favorite movie of all time. Deep, touching, heart-warming, great dramatic depth, storyline is great, and just a great ending that isn't cheesy and cliched. I highly recommend this.

I've just gone through the extra features such as deleted scenes and other extra little movies. They are all great just as extras to watch and good little tid bits to add onto the DVD. I plan on watching through with the commentary and what other else I can play with the movie.

Go see this movie. I say this has a great chance of winning an Oscar for best animated movie come award season. Pixar, look out.
The kids in my family watch this over and over for hours.  I highly recommend for little boys and girls.
This film is a winner. It grabs you and keeps you interested the whole time. The plot twists in ways you didn't see coming and the humor is sharp and constant. All Viking, All the Time!

I absolutely LOVED this move! It is one of my favorites! I have watched it many times with my boyfriend and this is DEFINITELY going to be his BDay gift!! :) A family movie with wonderful humor for all ages to enjoy!!  I would reccommend this for anyone!
This is a perfect film.  Equal to many other family fun films like, E.T., Mary Poppins, Toy Story, the Goonies, etc..  One you'll watch over and over again.

I enjoyed the movie in terms of the comedy and the characterizations, but I was extremely sorry that I brought my grandchildren to see it because of the dangerously naive message it conveys: If we are kind and understanding to our enemies, they will stop fighting us and become our friends. This is lovely in fantasy realms, but does anyone really believe it will work in the real world? Look at where this kind of thinking got Neville Chamberlain and Europe in WWII. I would not recommend this movie unless you want your kids and grandkids to be indoctrinated into allowing people to walk all over them.

This right here is the movie of 2010.
It is beautiful in style, very detailed, yet remains as a cartoon-like presentation.
While it is cartoon-like and child friendly, it touches base on a whole bunch of levels. It does not insult your intelligence, it does not resort to too much slapstick comedy but enough to make your child smile and laugh out loud once in a while.
As i stated earlier, it touches base on a lot of levels. It is a very deep movie, and will invoke a lot of feelings out of you even though this could be called a "boy and his dog" type movie. It is not that, it is so much more than that.

Out of all the movies this year, i have watched and re-watched this movie the most. It is beautiful and touching, and heartfelt. It uses just enough acting power to push the lines into believability, but not so much that the movie becomes about the actors instead of the lines they are reading and the powerful messages they send.

I suggest you get this movie, or atleast rent it to see why its so good.

I loved the movie--- loved it so much that I ended up reading the 7 books the movie is based from. The movie is definitely "inspired" from the books and Dreamsworks was successful in crafting their own version that would fit 1 feature length film.

My gripe is that in purchasing this blu-ray, there is no digital copy. Unlike Disney/Pixar, their blu ray releases automatically comes in with a regular dvd and digital copy. Dreamworks, please step it up for your customers.
This movie is great fun.  They manage to keep even the scary moments kind of "cute" so it is not too much for young children.  I really enjoyed it and so did my children.

This is a great movie for kids or even for the whole family. Went to the movies and saw this in 3D. As soon as this movie comes on blu ray I'm going to buy it. But the only complaint I have is why is there no digital copy to this release?. If you ask me I think all movies should have a digital copy to it.
I saw this movie in theaters several times, I fell in love with this movie! One of the best animated movies of 2010 by far. I can not wait to own this on Blu-ray!

When we initially went into the theater to see How to Raise Your Dragon, I wasn't expecting quite the story we wound up experiencing. The story we actually saw had more depth and more surprises than what I was expecting from an animated movie. I'm not going to go into the story. It is well documented. If you haven't read those reviews I don't want to be the one to provide the spoilers, but to be brief a Viking boy who is smart but a failure as a beefy warrior winds up with a different experience with the dragons his village has been at war with than his fellow villagers are having. You'll have a lot of fun as he learns to deal with his new situation, and astounds others with his new learned abilities.

The voice performances were convincing, and the animation was just plain fun. It was a more cartoon style animation than some of the more realistically based animated movies that have been produced recently, but that was just fine. The 3D in the theater was fun, but the Blu Ray will not disappoint. Colors in this movie are rich. Some of the dragons look dragon-scary, but some of them are silly and funny. Since this is a movie primarily for kids, the silly and funny dragons are just fine.

Highly recommended for family viewing.

My twelve-year old son and I found this movie unexpectedly excellent!  It is funny, clever, heroic and full of heart.  I loved the beautiful musical score. See if you can spot the Giant's Causeway in Northern Ireland about half-way though the movie.

Fun, adventure, great visuals, touching without being sappy, hard lessons without being preachy, and laughs that leave you chuckling at the memory every time you think about them. Is it Gone with the Wind? Of course not. But it is pure joy.

How To Train Your Dragon is an absolute masterpiece. It touched my heart and boy do I LOVE it!

The animation was breathtaking! Whenever Hiccup flies Toothless around I feel as though I am too! The cinematography was amazing and so was the scenery! Look out Pixar! DreamWorks is coming!

The score was beautiful!!! This is the only movie where I've gotten goosebumps from the music! (We'll besides Harry Potter) It's my Most Played on iTunes! Even if you haven't seen the movie yet the music will still give you the chills!

The characters are perfect in there own ways! Hiccup's sarcastic and witty attitude totally got to me because, well, I'm sarcastic and witty too! :) And Astrid's tough girl status totally showed that girl's can handle the action and adventure of battling dragons! And may we not forget Ruffnut and Tuffnut! They totally reminded me of my brother and I doing our fun/playful bickering! That just reminds me how much the character's relate to people! (Especially me!)

Just because the movie has a different storyline then the book doesn't mean this movie's a fail! The movie is different in a good way! So go see the BEST movie of the year! :) I give it two thumbs up!!! :D

The LA Times reported that "Dragon" was a disaster after 3 years of production. Dreamworks called in story smiths Chris Sanders and Dean Deblois of "Lilo and Stitch" fame to repair it in two more. Sanders and Deblois have a knack for mixing Cute and Vicious, and what better film than one that tells the story of domesticating a wild dragon?

The results are fantastic; the buzz was that animators actually working on the film were in tears seeing their finished scenes cut together. I don't know if that story is true, but the dramatic tension in "Dragon" is worthy of an 86-minute film, the cinematography of Roger Deakins (normally a live-action guy) is some of the best I've seen in an animated film, and definitely this year.

I know this statement won't make me popular: the 3-D is overrated, and at times inhibits the film experience. My wife got headaches viewing it at times, and I never fully bought the experience as I had a big freaking pair of glasses on the whole time.

This is a wonderful film for the whole family. We took our 4 year old grandaughter and she loved it so much we went again a few weeks later. It is entertaining for the adults as well as the kids and has enduring characters that you don't soon forget. If you missed it at the theater be sure to get it on DVD or Bluray for the family, you won't be disappointed.

The character designs looked cartoony, but real... hair looked like hair, skin like skin, etc. It was easy to become absorbed into it. My kids (2, 4) LOVED it. Where were all the toys and other merchandise usually associated with this kind of movie? We got the McDonalds toys-which they still play with MONTHS later. I think Walmart was the exclusive retailer, but even then their website offered almost nothing.

Want a cross between Toy Story and pokemon?  You get this stupid movie.  Since when do Vikings have an irish accent?  Since this movie apparently.  The dragons are laughable.  Some look like they're straight out of a kindergarteners art folder.  Not nearly menacing, and more laughable.  The only reason I gave this movie 3 stars is because the plot is ok.  I expected more from pixar.

I adore it. I mean, from what I am seeing, everyone seems to like it. It got great reviews and very few criticisms, great ratings on all the critic websites, great ticket sales, and the merchandise is selling like crazy. I bought the last plush Toothless at the WalMart in my hometown for $15. Next thing I know, they're up for $75 on Amazon!

Anyway, I really liked it. Toothless is the most loveable dragon. Hiccup is adorable, too. I love the cast. I think it was very well done.

I remember when I was in the theater with my friend who I convinced to go see it with me because it looked hilarious. As we were watching I felt a little embarassed, like, "okay.. this is really not THAT funny". But as the movie progressed I was more impressed with the story than some lame jokes and slapstick incorporated into a children's story. The ending nearly brought me to tears.

Fantastic movie. My favorite this year.
(Although I am concerned about the sequel and tv series that are coming from it's success. I'm worried it might cheapen the story.)
